searchDocs.title: But wait - what is Salesforce Explorer ?‚Äã
searchDocs.content: Salesforce Explorer is a productivity tool provided as a chrome extension intended for Salesforce administrators and developers. It contains features I needed on some of my previous assignments that I decided to package.

searchDocs.title: What is included ?‚Äã
searchDocs.content: Here is the list of the most important features provided:  Multi org Connect to multiple orgs to browse and compare records across them. Object Manager Retrieve key information on the objects you use the most. Explore Data Chain requests and query data across multiple orgs with ease Explore Code Extract JSDoc information from your LWCs and your Apex to generate a status report Explore Omnistudio Get an overview of your omniscripts, DataRaptors and your flexcards Explore Products Explore Insurance Products with their coverage, attributes, rules and dependencies Interact with ChatGPT Get contextualized help with ChatGPT to facilitate your work. Compare records Compare any other record in your orgs such as Flexipages, accounts or Flows.

searchDocs.title: But why?‚Äã
searchDocs.content: Most of the time I started working on something because I needed it on my project and I could not find the capability in salesforce or I was not comfortable with the user experience.

searchDocs.title: How is it built?‚Äã
searchDocs.content: It is built with React, Typescript and React SLDS to provide a salesforce like UX experience.

searchDocs.title: Why not an Appexchange?‚Äã
searchDocs.content: Web extension architecture offers the following advantages  First and foremost: No need to be admin of your org to install/use it!A single installation is enough for all your orgsReact, Typescript, webpack and friends offer a better developer experience than lwcInterestingly you can access the tooling API from a web extension and in LWC to do the same you need to a configuration with a connected app which is more complex in my opinion

searchDocs.title: Is it open source?‚Äã
searchDocs.content: Not yet, but the plan is to make it open source - code needs to be cleaned and documented first.

searchDocs.title: Can you use it on your project?‚Äã
searchDocs.content: Yes please try it out and let me know what you think. You can provide feedback here

searchDocs.title: Is it secure?‚Äã
searchDocs.content: Yes, like for the appexchange, chrome makes a security review for chrome extension and it has been approved

searchDocs.title: Introducing GenAI Explorer - Your Gateway to Salesforce AI
ü§ñ The Vision: Humans + Agents‚Äã
searchDocs.pageTitle: Introducing GenAI Explorer - Your Gateway to Salesforce AI
searchDocs.content: The future isn't humans or agents‚Äîit's humans and agents working together. But for this collaboration to succeed, we need transparency. We need to understand:  What did the agent do? Which actions were taken, which topics were matched, which data was accessed?Why did it do that? What reasoning led to those decisions? What context influenced the response?How can we improve it? Where are the bottlenecks? What optimizations are possible?  GenAI Explorer bridges this gap. It's not just about chatting with AI agents‚Äîit's about understanding them.

searchDocs.title: üåç Starting with Salesforce, Expanding Beyond‚Äã
searchDocs.pageTitle: Introducing GenAI Explorer - Your Gateway to Salesforce AI
searchDocs.content: While our initial focus is on Salesforce Agentforce and Einstein AI, our vision extends beyond a single platform. The principles of AI transparency, debugging, and optimization apply universally:  Today: Salesforce Agentforce, Einstein, Data CloudTomorrow: Multi-platform AI agent supportFuture: A unified lens for understanding any AI agent, anywhere

searchDocs.title: üöÄ What is GenAI Explorer?‚Äã
searchDocs.pageTitle: Introducing GenAI Explorer - Your Gateway to Salesforce AI
searchDocs.content: GenAI Explorer is a browser extension designed specifically for the Salesforce AI ecosystem. It provides a unified interface for interacting with your organization's AI agents, understanding their configuration, and analyzing their performance - all without leaving your browser.  Single Purpose: A developer and administrator tool for chatting with, testing, and monitoring Salesforce Agentforce and Einstein AI capabilities‚Äîwith transparency at its core.

searchDocs.pageTitle: Introducing GenAI Explorer - Your Gateway to Salesforce AI

searchDocs.title: üí¨ Chat with Agentforce Agents‚Äã
searchDocs.pageTitle: Introducing GenAI Explorer - Your Gateway to Salesforce AI
searchDocs.content: The headline feature - have real-time conversations with any Agentforce agent in your org:  Live Chat Interface: Start conversations instantlySession & Message Variables: Configure context for personalized interactionsCited References: See exactly what sources the agent usedConversation History: Browse and replay past conversationsReal-Time Testing: Test different scenarios and edge cases

searchDocs.title: How to Get Standard Object and Field Descriptions in Salesforce
üìä Visual Overview‚Äã
searchDocs.pageTitle: How to Get Standard Object and Field Descriptions in Salesforce
searchDocs.content: Here's how the SF Explorer ecosystem provides Salesforce metadata to different users:

searchDocs.title: üéØ The Challenge‚Äã
searchDocs.pageTitle: How to Get Standard Object and Field Descriptions in Salesforce
searchDocs.content: As Salesforce developers and administrators, we often need quick access to standard object and field descriptions. But navigating through Setup or hunting through the official documentation can be time-consuming and inefficient.  That's why we built a comprehensive ecosystem of tools to make this information readily accessible‚Äîwhether you're a user, developer, or administrator.

searchDocs.title: üöÄ Solutions for Every Use Case‚Äã
searchDocs.pageTitle: How to Get Standard Object and Field Descriptions in Salesforce

searchDocs.title: 1. üìñ For Users: Lightning-Fast Documentation Browser‚Äã
searchDocs.pageTitle: How to Get Standard Object and Field Descriptions in Salesforce
searchDocs.content: If you just want to browse the documentation with a really fast interface, check out:  üîó https://sf-explorer.github.io/sf-doc-to-json/  This web interface provides instant access to all standard object and field descriptions with:  ‚ö° Lightning-fast searchüé® Clean, intuitive UIüì± Responsive designüîç Comprehensive metadata coverage

searchDocs.title: 2. üíª For Developers: NPM Package‚Äã
searchDocs.pageTitle: How to Get Standard Object and Field Descriptions in Salesforce
searchDocs.content: If you're building an application that needs programmatic access to Salesforce metadata, you can consume the npm package directly:  npm install @sf-explorer/salesforce-object-reference   Benefits:  üì¶ Easy integration into your applicationsüîÑ Updated with each Salesforce releaseüéØ Type-safe access to metadataüöÄ No API calls required

searchDocs.title: What and why‚Äã
searchDocs.content: SF Explorer 4.0.0 is out with a focus on:  Improved performanceImproved UX and a new SOQL Query Editor (based on VSCode)A new feature: Data Dictionary Generation (from the object manager)

searchDocs.title: 3. üîß For Admins: Chrome Extension‚Äã
searchDocs.pageTitle: How to Get Standard Object and Field Descriptions in Salesforce
searchDocs.content: If you're an administrator who wants to add descriptions directly within Setup, install our Chrome extension that enhances your Setup experience:  üîó SF Explorer Advanced Setup  This extension:  ‚ú® Enriches Setup with field descriptionsüìù Shows documentation inlineüéØ Improves productivityüí° Makes configuration easier

searchDocs.title: 4. üìä For Architects: ERD Diagrams‚Äã
searchDocs.pageTitle: How to Get Standard Object and Field Descriptions in Salesforce
searchDocs.content: If you need Entity Relationship Diagrams (ERDs) by cloud with DrawIO charts:  üîó SF Explorer Diagrams  Features:  üó∫Ô∏è Cloud-specific ERDsüìê DrawIO format for easy editingüîó Visual relationship mappingüì• Export capabilities

searchDocs.title: 5. üåê For Your Org: Custom Data Dictionary‚Äã
searchDocs.pageTitle: How to Get Standard Object and Field Descriptions in Salesforce
searchDocs.content: And finally, if you want a complete data dictionary with objects and fields specific to your org, just connect to SF Explorer:  üîó app.sf-explorer.com  Get:  üìö Complete org metadataüé® Custom object documentationüîç Search across all metadataüìä Relationship visualizationüìù Data dictionary exports

searchDocs.title: üí∞ All Free, Most Open Source!‚Äã
searchDocs.pageTitle: How to Get Standard Object and Field Descriptions in Salesforce
searchDocs.content: The best part? All of these tools are completely free, and most are open source!  We believe in giving back to the Salesforce community by:  üÜì Providing free access to all toolsüåê Open-sourcing the codeüîÑ Keeping documentation up-to-dateü§ù Building for the community

searchDocs.title: üõ†Ô∏è How It Works‚Äã
searchDocs.pageTitle: How to Get Standard Object and Field Descriptions in Salesforce
searchDocs.content: Behind the scenes, here's what happens:  After each Salesforce release, our automated scripts parse the official Salesforce documentationWe extract all standard object and field metadata including descriptions, data types, and relationshipsThe data is published as an npm package (@sf-explorer/salesforce-object-reference)All our tools and interfaces consume this package to provide consistent, up-to-date information

searchDocs.content: Depending on your role and needs, pick the solution that works best for you:  Role	Use Case	Solutionüë§ User	Browse documentation	Web Interface üíª Developer	Build applications	NPM Package üîß Admin	Enhance Setup	Chrome Extension üìä Architect	Create ERDs	Diagrams üåê Any	Org-specific docs	SF Explorer

searchDocs.title: A CustomField API Name must be in english and PascalCase‚Äã
searchDocs.content: Field: DeveloperName Regex: ^[A-Z][A-Za-z0-9]*$  Example‚Äã  PhoneNumber

searchDocs.title: Custom Fields must have a Description (at least 20 chars)‚Äã
searchDocs.content: Field: Description Regex: ^.{20,}$

searchDocs.title: An Apex class name must be PascalCase and use a correct Suffix‚Äã
searchDocs.content: Field: Name Regex: ^[A-Z][A-Za-z0-9_]*(Controller|CallIn|CallOut|Test|Helper|Mapping|Mock|TriggerHandler|TestDataFactory|Wrapper|Constant|Batchable|Queuable|Schedulable|EntityManager|ServiceManager|DataManager)$  Example‚Äã  ActivityTimeline_ControllerActivityTimeline_Controller_TestRetrieveInteractions_ServiceOutRetrieveInteractions_ServiceOut_MockRetrieveInteractions_ServiceOut_Test

searchDocs.title: An ApexClass must follow the best practices‚Äã
searchDocs.content: Field: Body  Example‚Äã  No DML in loopOptimize SOQL with related listsNo Hardcoded values

searchDocs.title: An ApexClass must have a Description‚Äã
searchDocs.content: Field: Body.description  Example‚Äã  /** * BoatDataService exposes utilities to manipulate data related to boat * @author "John Doe" * @date 25/04/2023 **/ public with sharing class BoatDataService { public static final String LENGTH_TYPE = 'Length'; @AuraEnabled(cacheable=true) public static List<Boat__c> getBoats(String boatTypeId) { } }

searchDocs.title: An ApexClass must have an author‚Äã
searchDocs.content: Field: Body.author  Example‚Äã  /** * BoatDataService exposes utilities to manipulate data related to boat * @author "John Doe" * @date 25/04/2023 **/ public with sharing class BoatDataService { public static final String LENGTH_TYPE = 'Length'; @AuraEnabled(cacheable=true) public static List<Boat__c> getBoats(String boatTypeId) { } }

searchDocs.title: Apex variables must be camelCase‚Äã
searchDocs.content: Field: SymbolTable.variables Regex: ^[a-z][A-Za-z0-9]*$

searchDocs.title: Apex methods must be camelCase‚Äã
searchDocs.content: Field: SymbolTable.methods Regex: ^[a-z][A-Za-z0-9]*$

searchDocs.title: UI integration‚Äã
searchDocs.content: Once defined, errors will be showned contextually on your records as you navigate through SF Explorer:

searchDocs.title: Setup Enhancement‚Äã
searchDocs.content: Enhance your Salesforce setup with checks and best practices with a new chrome extension called SF Explorer Advanced Setup  It adds custom message into your Salesforce setup screen to enforce your project rules are enforced. Your Design Authority should be pleased! You can add a custom messages for:  New Custom Object New Permission Set Those messages are configurable in the option page. It prevent user from creating duplicate fields It shows similar fields when opening a custom field

searchDocs.title: Command line integration‚Äã
searchDocs.content: It is simple to integrate those rules in your current pipelines, for example with a Github Action:    Create a file named .env with the following content:  SFEXP_LOGIN=XXX # remove it to use SFDX instead SFEXP_PASSWORD=XXX # Password+SecurityToken, remove it to use SFDX instead LOGINURL=https://login.salesforce.com #or https://test.salesforce.com DATE=TODAY #or 2024-01-01 RULES=EntityDefinition,CustomField #specify to only run rules on EntityDefinition and CustomField - remove param to check all rules   To connect with SFDX, don't use the SFEXP_LOGIN/SFEXP_PASSWORD env var.  Run the command:  npx @sf-explorer/devops.cli   The command will generate an output file name testReport.xml (in JUnit format).

searchDocs.title: Ignore metadata‚Äã
searchDocs.content: You can ignore specific errors with a file named .sfexplorerignore (using regex similar to a .gitignore file)  ignore an author with @ and the author nameignore a record with its type and target

searchDocs.title: EntityDefinition‚Äã
searchDocs.content: A custom object Name must be in english and PascalCase A custom object Description is required Less than 100 custom fields Maximum one custom trigger per object Maximum 15 record types per object

searchDocs.title: CustomField‚Äã
searchDocs.content: A CustomField API Name must be in english and PascalCase Custom Fields must have a Description (at least 20 chars)

searchDocs.title: Flow‚Äã
searchDocs.content: Flow Description is required (at least 20 chars) Flow Label must be Short Yet Meaningful

searchDocs.title: PermissionSet‚Äã
searchDocs.content: Name is following project convention Description is required (more than 20 chars)

searchDocs.title: ApexClass‚Äã
searchDocs.content: An Apex class name must be PascalCase and use a correct Suffix An ApexClass must follow the best practices An ApexClass must have a Description An ApexClass must have an author Apex variables must be camelCase Apex methods must be camelCase

searchDocs.title: LightningComponentResource‚Äã
searchDocs.content: An LWC must have an author An LWC must have a description

searchDocs.title: FieldPermissions‚Äã
searchDocs.content: No field level security on Profiles (except System Administrator)

searchDocs.title: OmniUiCard‚Äã
searchDocs.content: Flexcards names must be pascal case Flexcards must have a description

searchDocs.title: OmniProcess‚Äã

searchDocs.title: Configurable systems in 2024‚Äã
searchDocs.content: Nowadays systems are by design more and more configurable. Don‚Äôt get me wrong, this is great. However in many cases this also gives back a lot of responsibility to the end user. Over the years, developers have invented many tools to help them in their day to day work, such as:  Code autocompletionCode reviewsDeployment pipelineAutomatic testingLintingand much more,...  Wait a minute‚Ä¶ What do we provide to our end user who is supposed to do something as heavy as configuring an insurance product? Not always much. This document is intended to explain how SF Explorer can help the product configurator in his day to day activity.

searchDocs.title: Why Product Explorer?‚Äã
searchDocs.content: The goal of Product Explorer is to help the Product Specialist in his configuration work that can be complex by providing:  An Helicopter View 360 degrees view of all layers, from product to attribute rule Dependency management Visualize dependencies between components Visualize recent changes at glanceBe alerted on configuration errors

searchDocs.title: Example‚Äã
searchDocs.content: The below example show a product class with 4 different product instances using many attributes. It is a particular good fit because many attributes are reused between coverages (which is often the case).  tip As a best practice try to name your attributes with a common name. For example, don't use Collision Limit but only Limit. We know it is a collision limit because it is in the collision coverage.  Here is what you should not do for example

searchDocs.content: Omniscripts and Integrations Procedures are grouped together as they are the same technical object. You can find them by using the Kind column.    info If you are still on a vlocity omnistudio org, you can change the namespace from here.    If you click on the Used By column you can find what FlexCard or other Omniscript use your given record.

searchDocs.title: Problematic‚Äã
searchDocs.content: A number of frameworks and project implementations use Custom Metadata and textarea to stored structured information in json or XML. The approach is powerful but today the Salesforce Admin UI is not appropriate for this type of manipulation as it lacks:  Automatic indentationCollapsing sectionsSyntax validationSyntax coloration  Today you have to manual copy into third party tools and it is error prone.

searchDocs.title: Proposed solution‚Äã
searchDocs.content: SF Explorer provides the missing edition capabilities with:  Ace Editor for syntax colorationStandard JSON parsing and validationDefault JSON formating with JSON.stringifySalesforce Metadata API to update the metadata in salesforce  Metadata can be retrieved and then edited from the query builder or the Metadata menu entry    Roadmap This feature is going to be enhanced with the folling tools: Prettier is going to be used in a future version for enhanced formating capabilitiesMonaco Editor is going to replace Ace Editor

searchDocs.title: Introduction‚Äã
searchDocs.content: SF Explorer parses your Apex code to find JS Docs annotations, This information is then available in the UI.

searchDocs.title: Example‚Äã
searchDocs.content: /** * @author John Doe * @date 25/04/2023 * @description BoatDataService **/ public with sharing class BoatDataService { public static final String LENGTH_TYPE = 'Length'; public static final String PRICE_TYPE = 'Price'; public static final String TYPE_TYPE = 'Type'; @AuraEnabled(cacheable=true) public static List<Boat__c> getBoats(String boatTypeId) { // Without an explicit boatTypeId, the full list is desired String query = 'SELECT ' + 'Name, Description__c, Geolocation__Latitude__s, ' + 'Geolocation__Longitude__s, Picture__c, Contact__r.Name, ' + 'BoatType__c, BoatType__r.Name, Length__c, Price__c ' + 'FROM Boat__c'; if (String.isNotBlank(boatTypeId)) { query += ' WHERE BoatType__c = :boatTypeId'; } query += ' WITH SECURITY_ENFORCED '; return Database.query(query); } }

searchDocs.title: Introduction‚Äã
searchDocs.content: The OpenAPI Specification (OAS) allows the description of a remote API accessible through HTTP or HTTP-like protocols. This description, which may be stored as one or more documents (such as local files or HTTP-accessible network resources), is called an OpenAPI Description (OAD)  SF Explorer Generate your org specific OpenAPI endpoints:  Generate specific object endpointsAdd custom apexAdd custom and standard actions exposed (invocables)Try out mode available => run against your orgDownload spec

searchDocs.title: Notebook approach‚Äã
searchDocs.content: Inspired by Jupyter Notebooks, Explorer Notebooks offer a dynamic and interactive computing environment tailored for Salesforce professionals. Here are some standout benefits:  Interactivity: Experience interactive coding like never before. Seamlessly interact with your Salesforce org to enhance productivity and engagement.Visualization: Leverage integrated support for data visualization with Mermaid and the robust SF Explorer toolkit. Transform your data into insightful visual narratives.Documentation: Enjoy rich Markdown support to embed text, links, and more directly within your notebook. Effortlessly document your code, explain methodologies, and share insights.Reproducibility: Share notebooks easily, preserving code, outputs, and documentation in a single file. Ensure others can reproduce your results with ease.EducationalUse: Perfect for onboarding and technical training. Instructors can create interactive assignments and tutorials, making learning more engaging and effective.Sharing: Promote and share notebooks effortlessly within your pipelines, supported by dedicated Custom Metadata. In summary, Explorer Notebooks provide a powerful and flexible environment for documentation, data analysis, visualization, and coding. Elevate your Salesforce experience today !

searchDocs.title: Order of execution‚Äã
searchDocs.content: If you're struggling to wrap your head around the Salesforce order of execution, you're definitely not alone. Salesforce Core alone involves 20 intricate steps, and when you add in other clouds like Data Cloud and Marketing Cloud, it can start to feel like a big bowl of spaghetti üçù. Luckily, SF Explorer is here to save the day! üöÄ This tool provides an interactive object visualization that makes understanding the Salesforce order of execution much easier. You can even export these visualizations to your Git or Confluence for easy sharing and collaboration. With SF Explorer, you can:  Visualize complex processes interactively: See how different steps interconnect and flow.Export visualizations: Easily share with your team via Git or Confluence.Simplify learning: Break down complex processes into manageable, visual chunks. So, if you‚Äôre tired of getting tangled up in Salesforce execution steps, give SF Explorer a try and streamline your understanding and collaboration!

searchDocs.title: Introduction‚Äã
searchDocs.content: What is GraphQL:  Specification for API Server + Query Language - Facebook 2015Single endpoint for all the resources, that can be aggregatedRequests only the necessary dataSchema-driven, enabling introspection - metadata friendlyWidely adopted through a fast growing community  Useful resources:  GraphQL FoundationLandscapeSalesforce docsoql-to-graphqlFull stack TutorialSF Community groupannual survey results

searchDocs.title: Usage with SF Explorer‚Äã
searchDocs.content: GraphQL offers very interesting use cases for salesforce. A number of tools are available in the community and SF Explorer ships with a built in version of GraphiQL with the following advantages:  No need to authenticate - as easy as it should beSOQL transition toolSample queries to get you startedLWC Generation with the graphql wire adapter  To give it a try navigate to Code and then select GraphQL:

searchDocs.title: Wait - what is Salesforce Explorer?‚Äã
searchDocs.content: Salesforce Explorer is a productivity tool provided as a web app or a chrome extension or intended for Salesforce administrators and developers.

searchDocs.title: Why did you build SF Explorer?‚Äã
searchDocs.content: Most of the features where built because I needed it on my projects. I usually work in design authorities so I need to understand quickly what is going on in multiple sandboxes. I am the first user and if it helps me, it may help others, so I decided to package it.

searchDocs.title: How is it built?‚Äã
searchDocs.content: It is built with React, Typescript and React SLDS to provide a salesforce like UX experience.

searchDocs.title: Is it open source?‚Äã
searchDocs.content: Some pieces are. You can find the different components here

searchDocs.content: Yes please try it out and let me know what you think. You can provide feedback here

searchDocs.title: The Problem‚Äã
searchDocs.content: Humans and agents are meant to live together, yet we need better tools to understand what agents have done and, more importantly, why.  As AI agents become integral to business operations, teams face key challenges:

searchDocs.title: Understanding AI Behavior‚Äã
searchDocs.content: ü§î Complex Reasoning: AI decision-making involves multiple stages and considerationsüîç Tracing Decisions: Need to understand why agents chose specific actions or responsesüìä Performance Visibility: Token usage, timing, and quality metrics require analysis

searchDocs.title: Testing & Validation‚Äã
searchDocs.content: üß™ Safe Testing: Need controlled environments to validate agent behaviorüîÑ Iteration Speed: Want to test and refine agents quicklyüêõ Issue Reproduction: Need to replay and debug specific interactionsüìà Data Analysis: AI data spans multiple objects and requires specialized queries

searchDocs.title: Configuration Management‚Äã
searchDocs.content: üó∫Ô∏è Component Relationships: Understanding how agents, topics, and actions connectüìã Version Control: Tracking which configurations are active vs. draftüéØ Impact Analysis: Knowing what will be affected by changes

searchDocs.title: Development Tools‚Äã
searchDocs.content: üîß Specialized Needs: AI development requires different tools than traditional Salesforceüí¨ Prompt Engineering: Testing different models, prompts, and parametersüìä Analytics Access: Analyzing conversation data for insights  In short: Teams need specialized tools to build, test, and optimize AI agents effectively.

searchDocs.title: How GenAI Explorer Solves This‚Äã
searchDocs.content: GenAI Explorer is the Chrome DevTools for Salesforce AI - bringing complete transparency, powerful debugging, and rapid iteration to AI development.

searchDocs.title: üîç Complete Visibility‚Äã
searchDocs.content: ‚úÖ See Inside AI Reasoning: Visual Atlas pipeline showing all 6 processing stages ‚úÖ Track Every Decision: View which topics matched, which actions executed, and why ‚úÖ Live Performance Metrics: Token usage, processing time, quality scores in real-time

searchDocs.title: üß™ Safe Testing Environment‚Äã

searchDocs.title: Why We Built It‚Äã
searchDocs.content: Humans and agents are meant to live together. But for this collaboration to succeed, we need transparency.  GenAI Explorer was created by Salesforce developers and AI engineers building Agentforce implementations who needed better tooling. The project started with a simple question:  "How can we see what's happening inside an Agentforce conversation?"  From that question came a comprehensive toolkit that answers:  What did the agent do? Which actions, topics, and data?Why did it do that? What reasoning led to those decisions?How can we improve it? Where are bottlenecks and optimization opportunities?

searchDocs.title: Our Vision‚Äã
searchDocs.content: Today: Salesforce Agentforce, Einstein, Data Cloud Tomorrow: Multi-platform AI agent support Future: A unified lens for understanding any AI agent, anywhere  The goal: Make AI agent behavior transparent and understandable, regardless of platform.

searchDocs.title: Chat with Agentforce Agents
searchDocs.keywords: agentforce chat conversation testing session variables

searchDocs.title: The Problem‚Äã
searchDocs.content: Testing and validating AI agents requires a safe environment where you can experiment without affecting production users.  When building Agentforce implementations, teams face these challenges:  ü§î Validation Uncertainty: How do you verify an agent behaves correctly before going live?üéØ Scenario Testing: Need to test specific customer contexts, edge cases, and error conditionsüëÅÔ∏è Limited Insight: Want to understand what the agent is thinking and which actions it choosesüîÑ Context Testing: Need to test with different user profiles, account types, and data scenariosüêõ Debugging Difficulty: When something goes wrong, you need to trace through the entire conversation  In short: You need a controlled environment to thoroughly test and understand your agents before deployment.  ‚ùå Manual Debugging: No way to replay or analyze past conversations‚ùå Slow Iteration: Deploy, test, debug, repeat - very slow feedback loop  Result: Developers and admins struggle to validate agent behavior, leading to production issues and frustrated users.

searchDocs.title: How GenAI Explorer Solves This‚Äã
searchDocs.content: GenAI Explorer provides a safe, interactive testing environment where you can:  ‚úÖ Chat in Real-Time: Instant conversations without deployment - test locally before going live  ‚úÖ Control Context: Set session and message variables to simulate any user scenario  ‚úÖ See Everything: View cited references, actions invoked, and reasoning steps  ‚úÖ Replay & Debug: Access complete conversation history with filtering and analysis  ‚úÖ Fast Iteration: Test changes immediately, no deployment cycle needed  ‚úÖ Multiple Scenarios: Test edge cases, error handling, and different user types in minutes  Impact: Reduce testing time by 80%, catch issues before production, and build confidence in your agent's behavior.

searchDocs.title: Overview‚Äã
searchDocs.content: The Chat interface allows you to test and interact with any Agentforce agent configured in your Salesforce org. You can start conversations, configure context, view cited references, and analyze agent responses in real-time.

searchDocs.title: 1. Select an Agent‚Äã
searchDocs.content: From the main interface:  Click on "Chat" in the navigationChoose an agent from the Agent BrowserThe agent details will display, including: Agent name and descriptionAssociated topicsAvailable actionsConfiguration status

searchDocs.title: 2. Start a Conversation‚Äã
searchDocs.content: Click "Start Chat Session" to create a new conversation with the selected agent.  Each session is independent and maintains its own context and history.

searchDocs.title: Live Chat Interface‚Äã
searchDocs.content: Send messages and receive real-time responses from your Agentforce agent:  You: How can I help customers with returns? Agent: I can help you process customer returns. First, I'll need to know...   Key Features:  Real-time message streamingMarkdown formatting supportRich media responsesInline citations

searchDocs.title: Session Variables‚Äã
searchDocs.content: Configure context variables that persist throughout the conversation:  Example Session Variables:  { "customerId": "001xx000001234AAA", "accountType": "Premium", "region": "North America" }   To Set Session Variables:  Click "Configure Session Variables"Add key-value pairsSave and continue chatting  The agent will use these variables to personalize responses and make better decisions.

searchDocs.title: Message Variables‚Äã
searchDocs.content: Pass dynamic data with individual messages:  Example Message Variables:  { "orderId": "ORD-12345", "amount": "299.99" }   To Use Message Variables:  Enter your message textClick "Add Variables"Provide variable key-value pairsSend the message

searchDocs.title: Cited References‚Äã
searchDocs.content: View sources and data the agent used to generate responses:  Each response can include:  Knowledge Articles - Referenced documentationData Records - Salesforce records usedExternal Sources - APIs or external dataPrompt Context - System prompts used  To View Citations:  Look for the citation indicator on agent messagesClick to expand the citations panelSee all sources with links to original records

searchDocs.title: Multi-Turn Conversations‚Äã
searchDocs.content: The agent maintains context across multiple exchanges:  Turn 1: You: What's the status of order 12345? Agent: Order 12345 is currently in transit... Turn 2: You: When will it arrive? Agent: Based on the shipping information, it should arrive on Friday... Turn 3: You: Can you expedite it? Agent: Yes, I can expedite that order for you. Let me process that...

searchDocs.title: Conversation History‚Äã
searchDocs.content: Browse and replay past conversations:  Features:  View all past sessionsFilter by agent, date, or topicReplay entire conversationsExport conversation logsAnalyze conversation patterns  To Access History:  Click "Conversation History"Select a past sessionView the complete conversation threadOptionally continue the conversation

searchDocs.title: Testing Different Scenarios‚Äã
searchDocs.content: Create multiple sessions to test different use cases:  Test Scenario 1: New Customer  Session Variables: { "customerType": "new", "hasAccount": false }   Test Scenario 2: Premium Customer  Session Variables: { "customerType": "existing", "accountTier": "premium", "loyaltyPoints": 5000 }

searchDocs.title: Real-Time Performance Monitoring‚Äã
searchDocs.content: Monitor agent response times and quality:  Response Time: Time to first token and total responseToken Usage: Input and output tokens consumedActions Invoked: Functions called by the agentContext Size: Amount of context usedQuality Score: AI-generated quality assessment

searchDocs.title: Session Management‚Äã
searchDocs.content: Manage multiple active sessions:  Actions:  Pause/Resume - Temporarily pause a sessionEnd Session - Gracefully close a sessionFork Session - Create a new session with copied contextShare Session - Export session details

searchDocs.title: Debug Mode‚Äã
searchDocs.content: Enable debug mode to see additional technical details:  Debug Information Includes:  Raw API requests and responsesPrompt templates usedToken counts and timingModel parametersError details and stack traces  To Enable Debug Mode:  Click the settings iconToggle "Debug Mode"Chat messages will now include debug panels

searchDocs.title: 1. Use Session Variables for Context‚Äã
searchDocs.content: Set consistent context at the session level rather than repeating it in each message.  Good:  Session Variables: { "customerId": "001xx..." } Message: "What are this customer's open cases?"   Less Efficient:  Message: "What are the open cases for customer 001xx...?"

searchDocs.title: 2. Test Edge Cases‚Äã
searchDocs.content: Create sessions with unusual or edge-case variables to ensure your agent handles them gracefully.

searchDocs.title: 3. Monitor Citations‚Äã
searchDocs.content: Always check what sources the agent is using to verify accuracy and relevance.

searchDocs.title: 4. Use Conversation History‚Äã
searchDocs.content: Review past conversations to identify patterns and improvement opportunities.

searchDocs.title: 5. Test Incrementally‚Äã
searchDocs.content: Start with simple queries and gradually increase complexity to isolate issues.

searchDocs.title: Customer Service Testing‚Äã
searchDocs.content: Session: { "customerId": "001...", "accountType": "Premium" } Test 1: "I need to return an item" Test 2: "Where is my order?" Test 3: "I have a billing question"

searchDocs.title: Sales Enablement‚Äã
searchDocs.content: Session: { "opportunityId": "006...", "stage": "Proposal" } Test 1: "What's the next best action?" Test 2: "Show me similar won deals" Test 3: "Generate a proposal summary"

searchDocs.title: Technical Support‚Äã
searchDocs.content: Session: { "caseId": "500...", "product": "Enterprise" } Test 1: "Diagnose this error" Test 2: "Suggest troubleshooting steps" Test 3: "Find related knowledge articles"

searchDocs.title: Agent Not Responding‚Äã
searchDocs.content: Verify the agent is active in your orgCheck your Salesforce permissionsEnsure Data Cloud is enabledReview session variables for errors

searchDocs.title: Slow Response Times‚Äã
searchDocs.content: Reduce context sizeSimplify queriesCheck Data Cloud query performanceMonitor token usage

searchDocs.title: Unexpected Responses‚Äã
searchDocs.content: Review cited referencesCheck prompt templatesVerify topic configurationEnable debug mode for details

searchDocs.title: Session Errors‚Äã
searchDocs.content: Clear browser cacheRe-authenticate to SalesforceCheck API limitsReview error logs in debug mode

searchDocs.content: Creating comprehensive test suites manually is time-consuming and often misses edge cases.  When testing AI agents, teams struggle with:  ‚è±Ô∏è Time Consuming: Manually writing dozens of test casesüîç Missing Coverage: Hard to think of all possible user inputsüéØ Real-World Gaps: Test cases don't match actual user behaviorüìù Repetitive Work: Copy-pasting from interaction logsüîÑ Iteration Speed: Slow to expand test coverageüí° Discovery: Not knowing what to test until users try it  In short: You need a fast way to build comprehensive test suites that reflect real user interactions.

searchDocs.title: Overview‚Äã
searchDocs.content: The Add Test Case feature provides two powerful ways to create test cases: manual creation for specific scenarios, and automatic creation from real agent interactions for comprehensive coverage.

searchDocs.title: Location‚Äã
searchDocs.content: The "Add Test Case" button is located in the test cases table toolbar (top right).  ‚îå‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îê ‚îÇ üìã 5 test cases ‚Ä¢ 3 types [üîÑ Refresh] [+ Add] ‚îÇ ‚îÇ ‚îÇ ‚îÇ [Test cases table...] ‚îÇ ‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îò   Button: Blue button with "+" icon labeled "Add Test Case"

searchDocs.title: When to Use Each Mode‚Äã
searchDocs.content: From Scratch:  Testing specific edge casesCreating targeted validation testsDocumenting expected behaviorBuilding baseline test cases  From History:  Capturing real user scenariosExpanding test coverage quicklyDocumenting actual agent behaviorCreating regression tests

searchDocs.title: Overview‚Äã
searchDocs.content: Build a test case manually by specifying the user utterance and expected outcomes.

searchDocs.title: Fields‚Äã
searchDocs.content: 1. User Utterance (Required)‚Äã  What it is: The question or statement the user sends to the agent.  Input: Multiline text field (2 rows)  Example:  What is my account balance?   Tips:  Be specific and clearUse natural languageMatch how users actually speakVary phrasing for similar tests  2. Expected Topic (Optional)‚Äã  What it is: The conversational topic you expect the agent to identify.  Input: Dropdown selector  Options: Loaded from your GenAiPlanner configuration  Example:  ServiceTopic BillingTopic SupportTopic   Tips:  Select a topic to enable action selectionChoose the most specific topicLeave blank if topic doesn't matter  3. Expected Actions (Optional)‚Äã  What it is: The actions you expect the agent to execute.  Input: Multi-select with checkboxes  Behavior:  Disabled until topic is selectedFiltered to show only actions from selected topicShows count: "5 action(s) available from 'ServiceTopic'"  Example:  Selected Topic: ServiceTopic Available Actions: ‚òë GetBalance ‚òë TransferFunds ‚òê CheckAccountLimit ‚òê UpdateProfile ‚òê ResetPassword 2 actions selected   Tips:  Select topic firstChoose all actions the agent should executeOrder doesn't matterCan select 1+ actions  4. Expected Bot Response (Optional)‚Äã  What it is: The text response you expect from the agent.  Input: Multiline textarea (3 rows)  Example:  Your balance is $1,234.56. You have available credit of $500.   Tips:  Be specific about key informationCan be partial or full matchLeave blank if response text doesn't matterFocus on factual content

searchDocs.title: Workflow‚Äã
searchDocs.content: Step 1: Click "Add Test Case" button ‚Üì Step 2: Select "Create from Scratch" tab ‚Üì Step 3: Fill in fields: - Utterance (required) - Topic (optional) - Actions (optional, needs topic first) - Response (optional) ‚Üì Step 4: Click "Add Test Case" ‚Üì Result: New test case added to table

searchDocs.title: Complete Example‚Äã
searchDocs.content: Input:  Utterance: "I need to transfer $500 to my savings" Topic: "TransferTopic" Actions: ["ValidateAccount", "TransferFunds", "SendConfirmation"] Response: "Successfully transferred $500 to your savings account."   Generated Test Case:  { "number": "6", "inputs": { "utterance": "I need to transfer $500 to my savings" }, "expectation": [ { "name": "topic_sequence_match", "expectedValue": "TransferTopic" }, { "name": "action_sequence_match", "expectedValue": "['ValidateAccount', 'TransferFunds', 'SendConfirmation']" }, { "name": "bot_response_rating", "expectedValue": "Successfully transferred $500 to your savings account." } ] }

searchDocs.title: Overview‚Äã
searchDocs.content: Convert real agent interactions into test cases by selecting from recent sessions.

searchDocs.title: Loading Process‚Äã
searchDocs.content: When you switch to the "Select from History" tab:  Step 1: Find Sessions  Queries recent sessions for your agentLimited to last 50 sessionsSorted by timestamp (newest first)  Step 2: Load Interactions  Gets all interactions from found sessionsLimited to last 100 interactionsFilters by agent name  Step 3: Load Related Data  Input/output messagesAction stepsTopicsChannel information  Step 4: Display  Combines all data per interactionShows rich preview of eachReady for selection  Loading Time: Usually 2-5 seconds depending on data volume.

You have ‚îÇ ‚îÇ ‚îÇ available credit of $500. ‚îÇ ‚îÇ ‚îÇ ‚îÇ 11/26/2025, 2:30:15 PM ‚îÇ ‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îò   Components:  Checkbox - Click to select/deselectUtterance - User's question (bold, quoted)Chips: üîµ Blue: Topicsüü£ Purple: Actions‚ö™ Gray: Channel (Chat, Voice, etc.) Response Preview - Bot's response (first 150 chars, italic, bordered)Timestamp - When the interaction occurred

searchDocs.content: Scenario: Your agent has been running in production, you want to test actual scenarios. searchDocs.title: Workflow 3: Regression Testing‚Äã
searchDocs.content: Scenario: You changed your agent, want to ensure it still handles previous scenarios.  Steps:  Before changes: Add test cases from historySave the evaluationMake agent changesRun testsSee what brokeFix agent or update expectations  Time: Initial setup 5 minutes, ongoing validation seconds  Result: Confidence that changes didn't break existing behavior

searchDocs.title: Workflow 4: Edge Case Testing‚Äã
searchDocs.content: Scenario: You discovered an edge case, want to add it to your suite.  Steps:  Test the edge case with your agentClick "Add Test Case"Tab: "Select from History"Find the recent interactionSelect itClick "Add Test Case"Save  Time: 1 minute  Result: Edge case permanently captured in test suite

Steps:  Chat with agent covering all topicsClick "Add Test Case"Tab: "Select from History"Select one interaction per topicClick "Add X Test Cases"Verify coverage in tableSave  Time: 10 minutes (including chatting)  Result: Full topic coverage in test suite

searchDocs.title: Creating from Scratch‚Äã
searchDocs.content: Do:  ‚úÖ Use natural language‚úÖ Be specific with utterances‚úÖ Select topic before actions‚úÖ Focus on key response content  Don't:  ‚ùå Use robotic or formal language‚ùå Leave utterance blank‚ùå Select actions without a topic‚ùå Expect exact response matches

searchDocs.title: Selecting from History‚Äã
searchDocs.content: Do:  ‚úÖ Review interactions before selecting‚úÖ Select diverse scenarios‚úÖ Check timestamps (use recent data)‚úÖ Bulk select related interactions  Don't:  ‚ùå Select failed interactions blindly‚ùå Ignore the response preview‚ùå Select too many at once (review first)‚ùå Forget to save after adding

searchDocs.title: After Adding‚Äã
searchDocs.content: Do:  ‚úÖ Review new test cases in table‚úÖ Click "Save" to persist‚úÖ Run tests to validate‚úÖ Edit expectations if needed  Don't:  ‚ùå Add too many without saving‚ùå Skip validation‚ùå Forget about auto-numbering‚ùå Ignore session match results

searchDocs.title: No Sessions Found‚Äã
searchDocs.content: Error: "No sessions found for agent: MyAgent"  Cause: No sessions exist for this agent yet.  Solution:  Chat with your agent firstWait for sessions to sync (~1 minute)Try again

searchDocs.title: No Interactions Found‚Äã
searchDocs.content: Error: "No interactions found for recent sessions"  Cause: Sessions exist but have no interactions.  Solution:  Ensure agent is properly configuredCheck that interactions are being recordedVerify Data Cloud setupContact admin if persistent

searchDocs.title: Load Failed‚Äã
searchDocs.content: Error: "Failed to load interactions: [error message]"  Cause: API error, permission issue, or network problem.  Solution:  Check Salesforce connectionVerify user has read access to Data CloudRetry loadingCheck browser console for details

searchDocs.title: Empty Utterance‚Äã
searchDocs.content: Alert: "Please enter an utterance"  Cause: User didn't fill in required field.  Solution:  Enter a user question in the utterance fieldTry adding again

searchDocs.title: No Selection‚Äã
searchDocs.content: Alert: "Please select at least one interaction"  Cause: User tried to add from history without selecting.  Solution:  Click to select one or more interactionsCheckbox should be checkedTry adding again

searchDocs.title: Test Case Numbering‚Äã
searchDocs.content: Automatic:  System finds highest existing numberIncrements by 1 for each new caseExample: If you have tests 1-5, new tests are 6, 7, 8, etc.

searchDocs.title: Expectation Formatting‚Äã
searchDocs.content: Topic:  { "name": "topic_sequence_match", "expectedValue": "ServiceTopic" }   Actions:  { "name": "action_sequence_match", "expectedValue": "['GetBalance', 'TransferFunds']" }   Response:  { "name": "bot_response_rating", "expectedValue": "Your balance is $1,234.56" }

searchDocs.title: Data Sources‚Äã
searchDocs.content: From Scratch:  Manual user input only  From History:  ssot__AiAgentSession__dlm - Sessionsssot__AiAgentInteraction__dlm - Interactionsssot__AiAgentInteractionMessage__dlm - Messagesssot__AiAgentInteractionStep__dlm - Steps

searchDocs.title: Query Limits‚Äã
searchDocs.content: Sessions: Last 50Interactions: Last 100Messages: All for selected interactionsSteps: All for selected interactions  Why limits?  Performance (faster loading)Relevance (recent data)UX (manageable list size)

searchDocs.title: Keyboard Shortcuts‚Äã
searchDocs.content: Coming soon:  Ctrl/Cmd + K - Open add dialogCtrl/Cmd + Enter - Add test caseSpace - Toggle selection (history mode)Esc - Close dialog

searchDocs.title: Q: Can I add test cases in bulk from scratch?‚Äã
searchDocs.content: A: Not directly in one action, but you can quickly add multiple by clicking "Add Test Case" after each entry. For bulk, use the history mode.

searchDocs.title: Q: How many interactions can I select at once?‚Äã
searchDocs.content: A: There's no hard limit, but we recommend reviewing them first. Selecting 10-20 at a time is typical.

searchDocs.title: Q: Do I need to save after adding?‚Äã
searchDocs.content: A: Yes! Click "Save" in the main view to persist your changes to Salesforce. The "isModified" indicator will show if you have unsaved changes.

searchDocs.title: Q: Can I edit test cases after adding?‚Äã
searchDocs.content: A: Yes, use the ‚úèÔ∏è Edit button on each test case row. See Test Case Editing.

searchDocs.title: Q: What if the history is empty?‚Äã
searchDocs.content: A: Chat with your agent first to create interactions, wait 1-2 minutes for data sync, then try loading history again.

searchDocs.title: Q: Can I filter or search history?‚Äã
searchDocs.content: A: Not yet, but it's on the roadmap. Currently shows most recent 100 interactions sorted by timestamp.

searchDocs.title: Q: What happens if I close the dialog without adding?‚Äã
searchDocs.content: A: All selections and inputs are discarded. Nothing is added to your test suite.

searchDocs.title: Q: Can I see the full conversation for an interaction?‚Äã
searchDocs.content: A: Currently shows a preview. Full conversation view is planned for a future release.

searchDocs.title: Q: How do I know which interactions are good test cases?‚Äã
searchDocs.content: A: Look for:  ‚úÖ Successful interactions (not errors)‚úÖ Clear user intent‚úÖ Representative of real use‚úÖ Diverse topics and actions

searchDocs.title: Q: Can I import test cases from a file?‚Äã
searchDocs.content: A: Not yet, but CSV/JSON import is on the roadmap.

searchDocs.title: Next Steps‚Äã
searchDocs.content: Test Case Editing - Refine your test casesEinstein Model Testing - Run your testsConversation History - Explore interactions    Fast test case creation leads to comprehensive coverage and confident deployments!

searchDocs.title: Atlas Reasoning Engine
searchDocs.keywords: atlas reasoning engine pipeline react data cloud query lab

searchDocs.title: The Problem‚Äã
searchDocs.content: Understanding what happens between sending a query and receiving an AI response is crucial for optimization and debugging.  When working with AI agents, you need to:  üîç Understand Processing: See how your queries flow through the AI pipeline‚ö° Identify Bottlenecks: Find which stages are consuming time or tokensüêõ Debug Issues: Trace where problems occur in the reasoning processüìä Analyze Performance: Monitor token usage, response times, and quality scoresüí∞ Optimize Costs: Identify opportunities to reduce token consumption  In short: You need visibility into the AI reasoning process to build better, faster, and more cost-effective agents.

searchDocs.title: How GenAI Explorer Solves It‚Äã
searchDocs.content: Atlas Reasoning Engine visualization provides complete transparency into AI processing:  Six-Stage Visualization: See the entire pipeline from chit-chat detection to safety gatesLive Data Integration: Query Lab runs pre-built queries against your actual Data CloudPerformance Metrics: See processing time and token usage for each stageComplete Reasoning Traces: Follow a request through all six stages with full detailsReady-to-Use Queries: 6+ pre-built SQL queries for common analysis tasks  Think of it as observability for AI - understand what's happening inside the black box.

searchDocs.title: The Problem‚Äã
searchDocs.content: AI agents are black boxes - you have no idea how they process queries or why they make certain decisions.  The visibility gap developers and AI engineers face:  ‚ùå No Transparency: Can't see the reasoning process behind agent responses‚ùå Unknown Pipeline: Don't understand the stages AI queries go through‚ùå Performance Mystery: No visibility into which stage causes delays‚ùå Debugging Nightmare: When something goes wrong, where do you even start?‚ùå Token Waste: Don't know which stages consume the most tokens‚ùå Data Inaccessibility: Performance data trapped in Data Cloud with complex queries  Result: Teams can't optimize AI performance, debug issues efficiently, or understand why their agents behave unexpectedly.

searchDocs.title: How GenAI Explorer Solves This‚Äã
searchDocs.content: GenAI Explorer opens the black box with:  ‚úÖ Interactive Pipeline Visualization: See all 6 Atlas stages in an intuitive diagram  Stage 1: Chit-Chat DetectionStage 2: Query EvaluationStage 3: Context RefinementStage 4: Query Planning & ExecutionStage 5: Advanced Retrieval (RAG)Stage 6: Quality & Safety Gates  ‚úÖ Query Lab: Pre-built Data Cloud queries to analyze real performance data  Complete reasoning tracesToken usage by model and stageProcessing time per stageSafety and compliance metrics  ‚úÖ Live Data Integration: Execute queries directly and see your actual org data  ‚úÖ Performance Insights: Built-in benchmarks showing 2x relevance improvement and 33% accuracy increase  ‚úÖ Educational Diagrams: ReAct loop, ERD diagrams, and data flow visualizations  Impact: Reduce debugging time by 70%, optimize token usage by 40%, and truly understand how your AI agents work under the hood.

searchDocs.title: Overview‚Äã
searchDocs.content: The Atlas Reasoning Engine is Salesforce's proprietary AI orchestration system that processes every query through a sophisticated pipeline. GenAI Explorer provides interactive visualizations and live data integration to help you understand exactly how your AI queries are processed.

searchDocs.title: What is Atlas?‚Äã
searchDocs.content: Atlas is the reasoning engine that coordinates:  Query understanding and intent classificationContext enrichment from your Salesforce dataAction planning and executionInformation retrieval from multiple sourcesResponse generation with citationsSafety and quality checks  Think of it as the conductor of an orchestra, coordinating multiple AI models, data sources, and safety systems to produce intelligent, grounded, and safe responses.

searchDocs.title: Stage 1: Chit-Chat Detection‚Äã
searchDocs.content: Purpose: Determine if the query is a genuine request or casual conversation.  Process:  Analyzes input textDetects greetings, pleasantries, or off-topic requestsRoutes to appropriate handler  Examples:  ‚úÖ Valid: "What's the status of order 12345?"‚ö†Ô∏è Chit-chat: "Hello, how are you?"‚ùå Invalid: "Tell me a joke"  Why It Matters:Saves processing time and tokens by handling simple interactions efficiently.

searchDocs.title: Stage 2: Query Evaluation‚Äã
searchDocs.content: Purpose: Determine if the query has enough information to be answered.  Process:  Checks for missing required parametersIdentifies ambiguous referencesValidates context sufficiency  Examples:  ‚úÖ Sufficient: "Show me orders from this customer" (with customer context set)‚ùå Insufficient: "Show me orders" (no customer specified)  Agent Response:"I need more information. Which customer's orders would you like to see?"  Why It Matters:Prevents wasted API calls and ensures quality responses.

searchDocs.title: Stage 3: Context Refinement‚Äã
searchDocs.content: Purpose: Enrich the query with relevant context from your Salesforce org.  Process:  Identifies entities mentioned (accounts, contacts, orders, etc.)Fetches relevant records from SalesforceAdds business context (account tier, region, history, etc.)Enriches with session variables  Example Enrichment:    Why It Matters:Context is key to accurate, personalized AI responses.

searchDocs.title: Stage 4: Query Planning & Execution‚Äã
searchDocs.content: Purpose: Create and execute a plan to answer the query using available actions.  Components:  LAMs (Large Action Models)‚Äã  Determines which actions to invokePlans the sequence of operationsHandles dependencies between actions  APIGen‚Äã  Generates API calls dynamicallyOptimizes query parametersHandles error cases  Example Plan:    Execution:  Actions run in parallel when possible (A1 and A2 run simultaneously)Results are cached for efficiencyErrors trigger fallback strategies  Why It Matters:Intelligent action planning reduces latency and improves accuracy.

searchDocs.title: Stage 5: Advanced Retrieval‚Äã
searchDocs.content: Purpose: Find and rank the most relevant information from all available sources.  Process:  1. Initial Retrieval‚Äã  Fetch candidates from multiple sources:  Knowledge articlesSalesforce recordsExternal APIsVector embeddings (RAG)  2. Re-Ranking‚Äã  Score and sort results by relevance:  Semantic similarityRecencyAuthorityUser preferences  3. Context Selection‚Äã  Choose the best information to include:  Most relevant resultsDiverse perspectivesWithin token limits  Example:    Why It Matters:RAG (Retrieval Augmented Generation) with re-ranking provides 2x relevance improvement.

searchDocs.title: Stage 6: Quality & Safety Gates‚Äã
searchDocs.content: Purpose: Ensure responses are safe, compliant, and high-quality before delivery.  Checks:  Toxicity Detection‚Äã  Offensive languageAggressive toneInappropriate content  Bias Detection‚Äã  Gender biasCultural biasAge bias  PII Protection‚Äã  Detects sensitive dataMasks PII automaticallyLogs PII usage  Accuracy Verification‚Äã  Fact-checking against sourcesConsistency checksHallucination detection  Compliance‚Äã  GDPR complianceIndustry regulationsCompany policies  Example Safety Gate:  Generated Response: "The customer's SSN is 123-45-6789. Their credit card..." After Safety Gate: "The customer's SSN is ***-**-6789. Their credit card..." PII Detected: Yes PII Masked: Yes Safety Score: 0.98 Allowed: Yes   Why It Matters:33% accuracy increase and ensures compliance with regulations.

searchDocs.title: The ReAct Loop‚Äã
searchDocs.content: Atlas uses the ReAct (Reason-Act-Observe) pattern for complex queries:    Why ReAct Matters:  Handles complex, multi-step queriesSelf-corrects when actions failAdapts to unexpected resultsExplains its reasoning

searchDocs.title: Data Cloud Architecture‚Äã
searchDocs.content: Atlas stores comprehensive data about every AI interaction in Data Cloud using a three-table structure:

searchDocs.title: 1. GenAIGatewayRequest‚Äã
searchDocs.content: Purpose: Incoming requests from users  Key Fields:  Request IDUser IDSession IDInput textTimestampModel requestedTemperatureMax tokens

searchDocs.title: 2. GenAIGatewayResponse‚Äã
searchDocs.content: Purpose: AI-generated responses  Key Fields:  Response IDRequest ID (foreign key)Output textCited sourcesToken usageResponse timeQuality scoreSafety scores

searchDocs.title: 3. GenAIGatewayGeneration‚Äã
searchDocs.content: Purpose: Token-level generation details  Key Fields:  Generation IDResponse ID (foreign key)Model usedInput tokensOutput tokensTotal tokensCost estimateProcessing stages

searchDocs.title: Three-Table Join Structure‚Äã
searchDocs.content: SELECT request.Id, request.InputText, response.OutputText, generation.TotalTokens, generation.Model FROM GenAIGatewayRequest request JOIN GenAIGatewayResponse response ON request.Id = response.RequestId JOIN GenAIGatewayGeneration generation ON response.Id = generation.ResponseId WHERE request.CreatedDate = TODAY

searchDocs.title: Query Lab‚Äã
searchDocs.content: Pre-built Data Cloud queries for analyzing AI performance:

searchDocs.title: 1. Complete Reasoning Trace‚Äã
searchDocs.content: Purpose: Follow the full request ‚Üí response lifecycle  SELECT r.CreatedDate, r.InputText, resp.OutputText, gen.Model, gen.TotalTokens, resp.ResponseTimeMs, resp.SafetyScore FROM GenAIGatewayRequest r JOIN GenAIGatewayResponse resp ON r.Id = resp.RequestId JOIN GenAIGatewayGeneration gen ON resp.Id = gen.ResponseId ORDER BY r.CreatedDate DESC LIMIT 100   Use Case: Debug specific conversations and understand exactly what happened.

searchDocs.title: 2. Token Usage by Model‚Äã
searchDocs.content: Purpose: Analyze costs and optimize model selection  SELECT gen.Model, COUNT(*) as RequestCount, SUM(gen.InputTokens) as TotalInputTokens, SUM(gen.OutputTokens) as TotalOutputTokens, SUM(gen.TotalTokens) as TotalTokens, AVG(gen.TotalTokens) as AvgTokensPerRequest FROM GenAIGatewayGeneration gen WHERE gen.CreatedDate = LAST_N_DAYS:7 GROUP BY gen.Model ORDER BY TotalTokens DESC   Use Case: Cost analysis and model optimization.

searchDocs.title: 3. Feature Usage Analysis‚Äã
searchDocs.content: Purpose: Track which AI features are most used  SELECT r.FeatureType, r.ActionInvoked, COUNT(*) as UsageCount, AVG(resp.ResponseTimeMs) as AvgResponseTime, AVG(resp.QualityScore) as AvgQuality FROM GenAIGatewayRequest r JOIN GenAIGatewayResponse resp ON r.Id = resp.RequestId WHERE r.CreatedDate = LAST_N_DAYS:30 GROUP BY r.FeatureType, r.ActionInvoked ORDER BY UsageCount DESC   Use Case: Identify most valuable features and optimization opportunities.

searchDocs.title: 4. Session Conversation Threading‚Äã
searchDocs.content: Purpose: Analyze conversation flows and context usage  SELECT r.SessionId, COUNT(*) as MessageCount, MIN(r.CreatedDate) as SessionStart, MAX(r.CreatedDate) as SessionEnd, AVG(gen.TotalTokens) as AvgTokensPerMessage, SUM(gen.TotalTokens) as TotalSessionTokens FROM GenAIGatewayRequest r JOIN GenAIGatewayResponse resp ON r.Id = resp.RequestId JOIN GenAIGatewayGeneration gen ON resp.Id = gen.ResponseId WHERE r.CreatedDate = LAST_N_DAYS:7 GROUP BY r.SessionId HAVING MessageCount > 1 ORDER BY MessageCount DESC   Use Case: Understand conversation patterns and multi-turn interactions.

searchDocs.title: 5. Safety & Compliance Monitoring‚Äã
searchDocs.content: Purpose: Track PII masking and safety scores  SELECT r.CreatedDate, r.UserId, resp.SafetyScore, resp.PIIDetected, resp.PIIMasked, resp.ToxicityScore, resp.BiasScore FROM GenAIGatewayRequest r JOIN GenAIGatewayResponse resp ON r.Id = resp.RequestId WHERE resp.SafetyScore < 0.8 OR resp.PIIDetected = true OR resp.ToxicityScore > 0.3 ORDER BY r.CreatedDate DESC   Use Case: Compliance reporting and safety auditing.

searchDocs.title: 6. Recent Requests Tracking‚Äã
searchDocs.content: Purpose: Monitor live AI activity  SELECT r.CreatedDate, r.InputText, resp.OutputText, gen.Model, resp.ResponseTimeMs, resp.QualityScore FROM GenAIGatewayRequest r JOIN GenAIGatewayResponse resp ON r.Id = resp.RequestId JOIN GenAIGatewayGeneration gen ON resp.Id = gen.ResponseId WHERE r.CreatedDate = TODAY ORDER BY r.CreatedDate DESC LIMIT 50   Use Case: Real-time monitoring and debugging.

searchDocs.title: Custom Evaluation Criteria
searchDocs.keywords: agentforce custom evaluations JSONPath string comparison numeric comparison test assertions action validation

searchDocs.title: The Problem‚Äã
searchDocs.content: Standard test expectations don't cover all testing needs.  When testing AI agents, teams need to validate:  üéØ Action Inputs: "Did the agent pass the correct account ID?"üìä Action Outputs: "Did the API call return success?"‚ö° Performance: "Was the response time under 10 seconds?"üî¢ Counts: "Were fewer than 5 API calls made?"üìù Data Formats: "Is the phone number formatted correctly?"‚úâÔ∏è Content Validation: "Does the email contain the customer's name?"  In short: You need granular control over what gets tested in agent responses.

searchDocs.title: How GenAI Explorer Solves This‚Äã
searchDocs.content: GenAI Explorer provides custom evaluation criteria with:  ‚úÖ Two Evaluation Types  String comparisons (equals, contains, starts with, ends with)Numeric comparisons (equals, greater than, less than, etc.)  ‚úÖ JSONPath Expressions  Extract any value from test resultsTarget specific action inputs/outputsAccess nested data structures  ‚úÖ Visual Editor  Guided dialog for creating evaluationsJSONPath pattern examplesReal-time preview of logic  ‚úÖ Flexible Assertions  Test exact matches or partial matchesCompare ranges and thresholdsValidate data formats

searchDocs.title: String Comparison‚Äã
searchDocs.content: Test text values with four operators:  Operator	Description	Exampleequals	Exact match (case-sensitive)	"Jon" equals "Jon" ‚úì contains	Substring match	"Hello Jon" contains "Jon" ‚úì startswith	Prefix match	"Hello World" starts with "Hello" ‚úì endswith	Suffix match	"example.com" ends with ".com" ‚úì

searchDocs.title: Numeric Comparison‚Äã
searchDocs.content: Test numbers with five operators:  Operator	Symbol	Description	Exampleequals	=	Equal to	10 = 10 ‚úì greater_than	>	Greater than	15 > 10 ‚úì greater_than_or_equal	>=	Greater or equal	10 >= 10 ‚úì less_than	<	Less than	5 < 10 ‚úì less_than_or_equal	<=	Less or equal	10 <= 10 ‚úì

searchDocs.title: Step 1: Open Test Editor‚Äã
searchDocs.content: Navigate to your AI Evaluation DefinitionClick Edit on a test caseScroll to the üî¨ Custom Evaluations sectionClick "Add Custom Evaluation"

searchDocs.title: Step 2: Configure Evaluation‚Äã
searchDocs.content: Example 1: Validate Email Recipient  Evaluation Type: String Comparison Label: Expected recipient match Operator: equals ‚òë Actual value is a JSONPath reference Actual Value: $.generatedData.invokedActions[*][?(@.function.name == 'DraftGenericReplyEmail')].function.input.recipient Expected Value: alice@example.com   Example 2: Check Subject Contains Keyword  Evaluation Type: String Comparison Label: Subject mentions project Operator: contains ‚òë Actual value is a JSONPath reference Actual Value: $.generatedData.invokedActions[*][?(@.function.name == 'DraftGenericReplyEmail')].function.input.subject Expected Value: project   Example 3: Response Time Threshold  Evaluation Type: Numeric Comparison Label: Response under 10 seconds Operator: less_than ‚òë Actual value is a JSONPath reference Actual Value: $.generatedData.latencyMs Expected Value: 10000

searchDocs.title: Step 3: Save and Test‚Äã
searchDocs.content: Click "Add Evaluation"Review the custom evaluation cardClick "Save Changes" on the test editorRun your test to see results

searchDocs.title: Understanding JSONPath‚Äã
searchDocs.content: JSONPath expressions extract values from the test results JSON structure.

searchDocs.title: Test Results Structure‚Äã
searchDocs.content: When you run a test, the agent generates data like this:  { "generatedData": { "invokedActions": [ { "function": { "name": "DraftGenericReplyEmail", "input": { "recipient": "alice@example.com", "subject": "Re: Project Update" }, "result": "Success" } } ], "latencyMs": 2500 } }

searchDocs.title: Common JSONPath Patterns‚Äã
searchDocs.content: Get Action Input Field‚Äã  $.generatedData.invokedActions[*][?(@.function.name == 'ActionName')].function.input.fieldName   Explanation:  $.generatedData - Start at root.invokedActions[*] - Look through all actions[?(@.function.name == 'ActionName')] - Filter to specific action.function.input.fieldName - Get the input field  Example:  $.generatedData.invokedActions[*][?(@.function.name == 'DraftGenericReplyEmail')].function.input.recipient   Returns: "alice@example.com"  Get Action Output‚Äã  $.generatedData.invokedActions[*][?(@.function.name == 'ActionName')].function.result   Example:  $.generatedData.invokedActions[*][?(@.function.name == 'CreateCase')].function.result   Returns: "Success"  Get Performance Metric‚Äã  $.generatedData.latencyMs   Returns: 2500

searchDocs.title: How Filtering Works‚Äã
searchDocs.content: Given this data:  { "generatedData": { "invokedActions": [ { "function": { "name": "DraftGenericReplyEmail", "input": { "recipient": "alice@example.com" } } }, { "function": { "name": "OtherFunction", "input": { "recipient": "bob@example.com" } } } ] } }   This expression:  $.generatedData.invokedActions[*][?(@.function.name == 'DraftGenericReplyEmail')].function.input.recipient   Returns: "alice@example.com" (not bob's email)  Why? The filter [?(@.function.name == 'DraftGenericReplyEmail')] only matches the first action.

searchDocs.title: 1. Validate Action Inputs‚Äã
searchDocs.content: Scenario: Ensure correct account ID is passed  Type: String Comparison Operator: startswith Actual: $.generatedData.invokedActions[*][?(@.function.name == 'GetAccountInfo')].function.input.accountId Expected: 001

searchDocs.title: 2. Verify Action Success‚Äã
searchDocs.content: Scenario: Check case creation succeeded  Type: String Comparison Operator: contains Actual: $.generatedData.invokedActions[*][?(@.function.name == 'CreateCase')].function.result Expected: Success

searchDocs.title: 3. Performance Testing‚Äã
searchDocs.content: Scenario: Response within 5 seconds  Type: Numeric Comparison Operator: less_than_or_equal Actual: $.generatedData.latencyMs Expected: 5000

searchDocs.title: 4. API Call Limits‚Äã
searchDocs.content: Scenario: Maximum 3 external calls  Type: Numeric Comparison Operator: less_than_or_equal Actual: $.generatedData.apiCallCount Expected: 3

searchDocs.title: 5. Data Format Validation‚Äã
searchDocs.content: Scenario: Phone number has country code  Type: String Comparison Operator: startswith Actual: $.generatedData.invokedActions[*][?(@.function.name == 'FormatPhoneNumber')].function.result Expected: +1

searchDocs.title: 6. Content Requirements‚Äã
searchDocs.content: Scenario: Email mentions customer name  Type: String Comparison Operator: contains Actual: $.generatedData.invokedActions[*][?(@.function.name == 'DraftEmail')].function.input.body Expected: {{customerName}}

searchDocs.title: Test Results Display‚Äã
searchDocs.content: Custom evaluations appear as purple columns (üî¨) in the test cases table:  Pass (‚úì):  Green checkmarkShows comparison detailsDisplays "10 < 10000" or "text contains 'keyword'"  Fail (‚úó):  Red error iconShows why it failedDisplays "alice ‚â† bob" or "15 ‚â• 10"  No Data (‚ö†):  Orange warning"No test session found to evaluate"Run the test to get actual values

searchDocs.title: 1. Use Descriptive Labels‚Äã
searchDocs.content: ‚úÖ Good:  "Expected recipient match""Subject contains project reference""Response time under 10 seconds"  ‚ùå Bad:  "Test 1""Check""Custom eval"

searchDocs.title: 2. Validate JSONPath First‚Äã
searchDocs.content: Before using complex expressions:  Run test with resultsInspect the generatedData structureTest your JSONPath against actual dataVerify it returns the expected value

searchDocs.title: 3. Remember Case Sensitivity‚Äã
searchDocs.content: String operators are case-sensitive:  "Jon" equals "jon" ‚ùå Does not match "Jon" equals "Jon" ‚úÖ Matches   For case-insensitive matching, use contains with known case.

searchDocs.title: 4. Start Simple, Then Expand‚Äã
searchDocs.content: First: Test basic fields (action names, simple inputs)Then: Add nested field comparisonsFinally: Use complex filters and conditions

searchDocs.title: 5. Character Limit‚Äã
searchDocs.content: Each parameter field is limited to 100 characters. For long JSONPath:  Break down complex pathsUse shorter action names if possibleConsider a different data structure

searchDocs.title: JSONPath Returns No Data‚Äã
searchDocs.content: Problem: Custom evaluation shows "No actual value found"  Solutions:  ‚úì Verify the action name is correct (case-sensitive)‚úì Check that the field path exists in generated data‚úì Ensure isReference checkbox is checked for JSONPath‚úì Run test to generate fresh data

searchDocs.title: String Comparison Fails Unexpectedly‚Äã
searchDocs.content: Problem: Strings that look the same don't match  Solutions:  ‚úì Check for extra whitespace (leading/trailing spaces)‚úì Verify case sensitivity ("Jon" vs "jon")‚úì Look for special characters‚úì Use contains instead of equals for partial match

searchDocs.title: Numeric Comparison Issues‚Äã
searchDocs.content: Problem: Numbers don't compare correctly  Solutions:  ‚úì Verify value is a number, not a string‚úì Check decimal places (10.0 vs 10)‚úì Ensure expected value is numeric‚úì Use appropriate operator (>= vs >)

searchDocs.title: Custom Evaluation Not Visible‚Äã
searchDocs.content: Problem: Evaluation doesn't show in results  Solutions:  ‚úì Save the test case after adding evaluation‚úì Verify metadata is properly formatted‚úì Refresh the page‚úì Check that column isn't hidden

searchDocs.title: Multiple Conditions‚Äã
searchDocs.content: To test multiple values from the same action:  Evaluation 1: Check recipient  Actual: $.generatedData.invokedActions[*][?(@.function.name == 'SendEmail')].function.input.to Expected: alice@example.com   Evaluation 2: Check subject  Actual: $.generatedData.invokedActions[*][?(@.function.name == 'SendEmail')].function.input.subject Expected: Project Update

searchDocs.title: Array Elements‚Äã
searchDocs.content: Access specific array items:  $.generatedData.invokedActions[*][?(@.function.name == 'ActionName')].additionalContext[0].value   The [0] gets the first context item.

searchDocs.title: Nested Properties‚Äã
searchDocs.content: Navigate deep structures:  $.generatedData.invokedActions[*][?(@.function.name == 'ComplexAction')].function.input.metadata.customField.value

searchDocs.title: Quick Reference‚Äã
searchDocs.content: Need	Type	Operator	Example UseExact match	String	equals	Verify recipient Contains text	String	contains	Check keywords Starts with	String	startswith	Validate prefix Ends with	String	endswith	Check domain Performance	Numeric	&lt; or &lt;=	Response time Limits	Numeric	&lt;=	API call count Thresholds	Numeric	&gt; or &gt;=	Minimum value Ranges	Numeric	Multiple evals	Min and max

searchDocs.title: Einstein Model Testing
searchDocs.keywords: einstein models testing gpt-4 comparison llm

searchDocs.title: The Problem‚Äã
searchDocs.content: Choosing the right AI model for your use case requires understanding the tradeoffs between cost, speed, and quality.  When building AI solutions, teams need to:  üéØ Model Selection: Determine which model provides the best balance for specific use casesüí∞ Cost Optimization: Understand token consumption and pricing implications‚ö° Performance Testing: Compare response times across different modelsüé® Quality Assessment: Evaluate output quality for your specific promptsüîß Parameter Tuning: Experiment with temperature, max tokens, and other settingsüìä Side-by-Side Comparison: Test multiple models with identical inputs  In short: You need a sandbox to experiment with different models and parameters before committing to production.

searchDocs.title: How GenAI Explorer Solves This‚Äã
searchDocs.content: GenAI Explorer provides comprehensive model testing with:  ‚úÖ Side-by-Side Comparison: Test multiple models with identical prompts simultaneously  ‚úÖ Parameter Control: Adjust and understand key settings  Temperature (creativity vs consistency)Max tokens (response length limits)Top-p, frequency penalty, presence penalty  ‚úÖ Cost Transparency: See token usage and estimated costs in real-time  ‚úÖ Performance Metrics: Compare response time, quality, and token efficiency  ‚úÖ Sample Prompts Library: Pre-built prompts for common scenarios  Customer service responsesData analysisCode generationCreative writing  ‚úÖ A/B Testing: Save and compare results across multiple test runs  Impact: Choose the right model for each use case, reduce costs by 50-70% with smarter model selection, and validate quality before deployment.

searchDocs.title: Overview‚Äã
searchDocs.content: The Einstein Model Testing interface allows you to experiment with different AI models, adjust generation parameters, and compare results side-by-side. This is essential for selecting the right model for your use case and optimizing your AI implementation.

searchDocs.title: GPT-4 Omni‚Äã
searchDocs.content: Best for: Complex reasoning, detailed analysis, multi-step tasks  Specifications:  Context window: 128K tokensMax output: 4096 tokensCost: HigherSpeed: SlowerQuality: Highest  Use Cases:  Complex problem-solvingDetailed explanationsCode generation and reviewMulti-step reasoningCreative content

searchDocs.title: GPT-4o Mini‚Äã
searchDocs.content: Best for: Fast, cost-effective general tasks  Specifications:  Context window: 128K tokensMax output: 4096 tokensCost: MediumSpeed: FastQuality: High  Use Cases:  Quick responsesSimple queriesHigh-volume applicationsReal-time chatSummarization

searchDocs.title: GPT-3.5 Turbo‚Äã
searchDocs.content: Best for: Simple, efficient tasks with fast response times  Specifications:  Context window: 16K tokensMax output: 4096 tokensCost: LowerSpeed: FastestQuality: Good  Use Cases:  Simple questionsData extractionClassificationTranslationBasic chat

searchDocs.title: 1. Access Model Testing‚Äã
searchDocs.content: Navigate to Einstein Model Testing from the main menu.

searchDocs.title: 2. Select a Model‚Äã
searchDocs.content: Choose one or more models to test:  ‚òê GPT-4 Omni‚òê GPT-4o Mini‚òê GPT-3.5 Turbo  Pro Tip: Select multiple models to compare results side-by-side.

searchDocs.title: 3. Configure Parameters‚Äã
searchDocs.content: Adjust generation parameters to control behavior:  Temperature (0.0 - 2.0)‚Äã  Controls randomness and creativity  0.0 - 0.3: Deterministic, factual, consistent Use for: Data extraction, classification, coding 0.4 - 0.7: Balanced creativity and coherence Use for: General chat, explanations, Q&A 0.8 - 1.2: Creative, varied responses Use for: Brainstorming, content creation, stories 1.3 - 2.0: Highly creative, unpredictable Use for: Creative writing, experimental outputs  Default: 0.7  Max Tokens (1 - 4096)‚Äã  Controls response length  50-100: Brief, concise answers200-500: Paragraph-length responses500-1000: Detailed explanations1000-2000: Comprehensive answers2000-4096: Very long, detailed content  Default: 500  Top P (0.0 - 1.0)‚Äã  Nucleus sampling - alternative to temperature  0.1: Very focused, deterministic0.5: Balanced0.9: More diverse1.0: Full diversity  Default: 1.0  Note: Use either temperature OR top_p, not both.  Frequency Penalty (0.0 - 2.0)‚Äã  Reduces repetition of tokens based on frequency  0.0: No penalty, allows repetition0.5: Moderate penalty1.0: Strong penalty2.0: Maximum penalty  Default: 0.0  Presence Penalty (0.0 - 2.0)‚Äã  Reduces repetition of topics already mentioned  0.0: No penalty0.5: Moderate penalty1.0: Strong penalty2.0: Maximum penalty  Default: 0.0

searchDocs.title: 4. Enter Your Prompt‚Äã
searchDocs.content: Type or paste your prompt in the text area.  Pro Tip: Use the sample prompts to get started quickly.

searchDocs.title: 5. Generate Response‚Äã
searchDocs.content: Click Generate to send the prompt to the selected model(s).  Results appear in real-time below the prompt area.

searchDocs.title: Story Generation‚Äã
searchDocs.content: Write a short story about a robot learning to appreciate art. Include a plot twist and make it emotional.   Recommended Settings:  Model: GPT-4 OmniTemperature: 0.9Max Tokens: 1000

searchDocs.title: Customer Service Response‚Äã
searchDocs.content: Generate a professional customer service response to this complaint: "I ordered my package 2 weeks ago and it still hasn't arrived. This is unacceptable. I want a refund." Tone: Empathetic and professional Include: Apology, explanation, solution, timeline   Recommended Settings:  Model: GPT-4o MiniTemperature: 0.6Max Tokens: 300

searchDocs.title: Code Explanation‚Äã
searchDocs.content: Explain this TypeScript function in simple terms: const debounce = <T extends (...args: any[]) => any>( func: T, delay: number ): ((...args: Parameters<T>) => void) => { let timeoutId: NodeJS.Timeout; return (...args: Parameters<T>) => { clearTimeout(timeoutId); timeoutId = setTimeout(() => func(...args), delay); }; };   Recommended Settings:  Model: GPT-4 OmniTemperature: 0.3Max Tokens: 500

searchDocs.title: Summarization‚Äã
searchDocs.content: Summarize this article in 3 bullet points: [Paste article text here] Focus on: key findings, practical implications, and recommendations.   Recommended Settings:  Model: GPT-3.5 TurboTemperature: 0.4Max Tokens: 200

searchDocs.title: Data Extraction‚Äã
searchDocs.content: Extract the following information from this email and return as JSON: - Sender name - Company name - Requested meeting date - Meeting purpose - Urgency level (low/medium/high) Email: "Hi, I'm Sarah from Acme Corporation. I'd like to schedule a meeting next Tuesday to discuss our Q4 partnership opportunities. This is quite urgent as we need to finalize contracts by end of month."   Recommended Settings:  Model: GPT-3.5 TurboTemperature: 0.0Max Tokens: 150

searchDocs.title: Creative Brainstorming‚Äã
searchDocs.content: Brainstorm 10 creative names for a new app that helps remote teams collaborate on design projects. The names should be: - Memorable - Easy to spell - Available as .com domains - Modern and tech-forward   Recommended Settings:  Model: GPT-4o MiniTemperature: 1.0Max Tokens: 400
