searchDocs.title: 1. Start Simple‚Äã
searchDocs.content: Begin with basic prompts and gradually increase complexity.

searchDocs.title: 2. Use Appropriate Models‚Äã
searchDocs.content: GPT-4 Omni: Complex tasks requiring deep reasoningGPT-4o Mini: General purpose, balanced quality/speedGPT-3.5 Turbo: Simple, high-volume tasks

searchDocs.title: 3. Optimize Temperature‚Äã
searchDocs.content: Factual tasks: 0.0 - 0.3Balanced: 0.4 - 0.7Creative: 0.8 - 1.2

searchDocs.title: 4. Control Token Usage‚Äã
searchDocs.content: Set max_tokens based on expected response length to avoid unnecessary costs.

searchDocs.title: 5. Test Consistency‚Äã
searchDocs.content: Run the same prompt multiple times (especially with temperature > 0) to ensure consistent quality.

searchDocs.title: 6. Compare Before Deploying‚Äã
searchDocs.content: Always test with multiple models before choosing one for production use.

searchDocs.title: 7. Use Custom System Prompts‚Äã
searchDocs.content: Tailor the system prompt to your specific domain or use case for better results.

searchDocs.title: 8. Monitor Costs‚Äã
searchDocs.content: Track token usage and costs, especially when testing with GPT-4 models.

searchDocs.title: Slow Response Times‚Äã
searchDocs.content: Try a faster model (GPT-4o Mini or GPT-3.5 Turbo)Reduce max_tokensSimplify the promptCheck Salesforce API limits

searchDocs.title: Low Quality Responses‚Äã
searchDocs.content: Switch to GPT-4 Omni for complex tasksIncrease max_tokens for longer responsesAdd more context to the promptUse a custom system promptAdjust temperature for more/less creativity

searchDocs.title: Inconsistent Results‚Äã
searchDocs.content: Lower temperature for more consistencyTest multiple times to verifyAdd more specific instructionsUse examples in the prompt

searchDocs.title: Token Limit Errors‚Äã
searchDocs.content: Reduce max_tokens settingShorten the input promptRemove unnecessary contextSplit into multiple requests

searchDocs.content: 1. Use the Right Model  Don't use GPT-4 Omni for simple tasksGPT-3.5 Turbo is 15x cheaper for basic queries  2. Limit Token Usage  Set appropriate max_tokensKeep prompts conciseRemove unnecessary context  3. Cache Responses  Store and reuse common responsesAvoid regenerating static content  4. Batch Requests  Process multiple items together when possibleReduces overhead  5. Monitor Usage  Track costs regularlySet budget alertsIdentify optimization opportunities

searchDocs.title: What is GenAI Explorer?‚Äã
searchDocs.content: GenAI Explorer is a Chrome extension for Salesforce developers and administrators to explore, test, and monitor Agentforce and Einstein AI capabilities. It provides tools for chatting with agents, testing models, analyzing performance, and understanding AI configuration.

searchDocs.title: Is GenAI Explorer free?‚Äã
searchDocs.content: Yes, GenAI Explorer is free to install and use. However, it requires a Salesforce org with Agentforce or Einstein AI features enabled, which may have associated licensing costs from Salesforce.

searchDocs.title: Which Salesforce editions are supported?‚Äã
searchDocs.content: GenAI Explorer works with any Salesforce edition that has Agentforce or Einstein AI enabled, including:  Enterprise EditionUnlimited EditionDeveloper Edition (with Einstein features)

searchDocs.title: Do I need special permissions?‚Äã
searchDocs.content: Yes, you need:  Einstein AI User permissionData Cloud access (for analytics features)Read access to AI metadata objectsAPI Enabled permission  Contact your Salesforce administrator if you don't have these permissions.

searchDocs.title: How do I install GenAI Explorer?‚Äã
searchDocs.content: Chrome Extension (Recommended):  Visit the GenAI Explorer Chrome Web Store pageClick "Add to Chrome"Click the extension icon and connect to your Salesforce org  Web Application:Visit https://app.sf-explorer.com/gen-ai.html to use GenAI Explorer without installing an extension

searchDocs.title: Can I use GenAI Explorer in multiple orgs?‚Äã
searchDocs.content: Yes! You can connect to multiple Salesforce orgs and switch between them:  Click the org dropdownSelect "Add Org"Authenticate to the new org

searchDocs.title: Does GenAI Explorer work in incognito mode?‚Äã
searchDocs.content: Yes, but you need to enable it:  Go to chrome://extensionsFind GenAI ExplorerClick "Details"Enable "Allow in incognito"

searchDocs.title: Can I use it on mobile?‚Äã
searchDocs.content: Not currently. GenAI Explorer is designed for desktop Chrome. Mobile browser extensions have limited functionality.

searchDocs.title: What can I do with GenAI Explorer?‚Äã
searchDocs.content: Core Features:  Chat with Agentforce agents in real-timeTest Einstein AI modelsVisualize the Atlas reasoning pipelineExecute Data Cloud queriesBrowse agent configurationsCreate visual documentation boardsMonitor AI performance metrics

searchDocs.title: Can I create or modify agents?‚Äã
searchDocs.content: No, GenAI Explorer is a read-only exploration tool. To create or modify agents, use Salesforce Setup. However, you can:  View all agent configurationsTest agent behaviorDocument agent designExport configurations

searchDocs.title: Does it support custom AI models?‚Äã
searchDocs.content: GenAI Explorer works with Einstein-supported models:  GPT-4 OmniGPT-4o MiniGPT-3.5 Turbo  Custom or external models aren't currently supported.

searchDocs.title: Can I share boards with my team?‚Äã
searchDocs.content: Yes, you can:  Export boards as JSON filesExport as images (PNG, JPEG, SVG)Share files via email or collaboration toolsOthers can import JSON files

searchDocs.title: Where is my data stored?‚Äã
searchDocs.content: Local Storage:  Boards and preferences stored in browserNo data sent to external servers  Salesforce Storage:  All query results from your Salesforce orgAI conversations stored in Data CloudNo data stored outside your control

searchDocs.title: Does GenAI Explorer collect my data?‚Äã
searchDocs.content: No. GenAI Explorer:  Does NOT collect personal informationDoes NOT send data to external servers (outside our heroku server to overcome cors)Only connects directly to your Salesforce org

searchDocs.title: Is my Salesforce data secure?‚Äã
searchDocs.content: Yes:  Uses official Salesforce OAuth authenticationAll connections are encrypted (HTTPS)No data stored externallyFollows Salesforce security best practices

searchDocs.title: Why aren't my agents responding?‚Äã
searchDocs.content: Common reasons:  Agent is inactive in SalesforceMissing required session variablesNo topics configured for the queryAPI limits exceededNetwork connectivity issues  See FAQ for more solutions.

searchDocs.title: Can I test agents in sandbox?‚Äã
searchDocs.content: Yes! GenAI Explorer works with:  Production orgsSandbox orgsScratch orgsDeveloper orgs

searchDocs.title: How do session variables work?‚Äã
searchDocs.content: Session variables provide context for the entire conversation:  Example:  { "customerId": "001xx000003D8E5", "accountType": "Premium" }   The agent uses these throughout the session without you repeating them.

searchDocs.title: What are cited references?‚Äã
searchDocs.content: Cited references show the sources the agent used to generate its response:  Knowledge articlesSalesforce recordsExternal data sourcesAPI responses  This helps verify accuracy and understand reasoning.

searchDocs.title: Do I need Data Cloud to use GenAI Explorer?‚Äã
searchDocs.content: Not for all features:  Requires Data Cloud:  Query LabPerformance analyticsToken usage reportsConversation threading analysis  Works Without Data Cloud:  Chat with agentsModel testingConfiguration browserInteractive boards (most features)

searchDocs.title: How do I access Data Cloud?‚Äã
searchDocs.content: Contact your Salesforce administrator to:  Enable Data Cloud in your orgGrant you Data Cloud User permissionSet up required permissions on AI objects

searchDocs.title: Why are my queries slow?‚Äã
searchDocs.content: Common Causes:  Missing date filtersToo many JOINsLarge result setsUnindexed fields  Solutions:  Always filter by CreatedDateUse LIMIT clauseQuery indexed fieldsSee Data Cloud Integration for optimization tips

searchDocs.title: Can I query custom objects?‚Äã
searchDocs.content: Yes, if they're available in Data Cloud. Use standard SOQL syntax with the correct API names.

searchDocs.title: Why do I get different results each time?‚Äã
searchDocs.content: This is normal AI behavior controlled by the temperature parameter:  Temperature = 0.0:  Most deterministicConsistent results  Temperature = 0.7:  Balanced creativitySome variation  Temperature = 1.5:  Very creativeHighly variable

searchDocs.title: How much do model tests cost?‚Äã
searchDocs.content: Each test consumes Einstein AI credits based on:  Model used (GPT-4 costs more than GPT-3.5)Token count (input + output)Your org's Einstein pricing  Check token usage in the results panel.

searchDocs.title: Can I test with production data?‚Äã
searchDocs.content: Yes, but be careful:  Don't expose PII in promptsTest in sandbox first for sensitive scenariosMonitor token usage to control costsFollow your organization's data policies

searchDocs.title: What's the difference between the models?‚Äã
searchDocs.content: Model	Speed	Cost	Quality	Best ForGPT-4 Omni	Slower	Higher	Best	Complex reasoning GPT-4o Mini	Fast	Medium	High	General purpose GPT-3.5 Turbo	Fastest	Lower	Good	Simple tasks

searchDocs.title: How many boards can I create?‚Äã
searchDocs.content: Limited only by browser storage (typically ~10MB). Most users can create 50-100 boards depending on complexity.

searchDocs.title: Can I embed live data in boards?‚Äã
searchDocs.content: Yes! Use Query Nodes to:  Execute SOQL queriesDisplay live resultsAuto-refresh dataExport updated data

searchDocs.title: What is the Board Prompt Engine?‚Äã
searchDocs.content: An AI-powered feature that lets you modify boards using natural language:  Example Commands:  "Add a markdown node at (100, 100)""Arrange all nodes in a grid""Connect the agent node to the topics"

searchDocs.title: How do I backup my boards?‚Äã
searchDocs.content: Best Practice:  Click "Export" on each boardSave as JSON fileStore in version control or backup locationRe-import if needed

searchDocs.title: Are there API limits?‚Äã
searchDocs.content: Yes, GenAI Explorer uses Salesforce APIs, which have limits:  Typical Limits:  15,000-100,000 API calls per day (depends on edition)Data Cloud query limitsEinstein AI credit limits  The extension monitors usage and warns at 80% capacity.

searchDocs.title: Why is the extension slow?‚Äã
searchDocs.content: Common Causes:  Too many open tabsLarge boards with many nodesAuto-refreshing queriesLimited browser resources  Solutions:  Close unused tabsSimplify boardsDisable auto-refreshClear browser cache

searchDocs.title: How much memory does it use?‚Äã
searchDocs.content: Typically 50-200MB depending on:  Number of open tabsBoard complexityQuery result sizesChat history length

searchDocs.title: How do I report a bug?‚Äã
searchDocs.content: Enable Debug ModeReproduce the issueExport debug logsOpen an issue with: Steps to reproduceError messagesDebug logsChrome versionSalesforce org edition

searchDocs.title: Where can I get help?‚Äã
searchDocs.content: Resources:  DocumentationGitHub Issues (for bug reports)Salesforce Trailblazer Community

searchDocs.title: Can I request new features?‚Äã
searchDocs.content: Yes! Feature requests are welcome:  Open a GitHub issueDescribe the use caseExplain the benefitInclude examples if possible

searchDocs.title: Can I automate tasks?‚Äã
searchDocs.content: GenAI Explorer is primarily a UI tool. For automation:  Use Salesforce APIs directlyExport configurations for scriptingUse SFDX for deploymentsConsider custom integrations

searchDocs.title: Does it support CI/CD?‚Äã
searchDocs.content: Yes, indirectly:  Export agent configurations as metadataUse with Salesforce DXVersion control exported JSONDeploy using standard SFDX tools

searchDocs.title: Can I customize the interface?‚Äã
searchDocs.content: Not currently. The UI is fixed, but you can:  Create custom boards for your workflowExport data for external toolsUse saved queries for repeated tasks

searchDocs.title: Is there an API?‚Äã
searchDocs.content: GenAI Explorer doesn't provide its own API, but it helps you work with:  Salesforce REST APISalesforce GraphQL APITooling APIData Cloud API

searchDocs.title: What should I try first?‚Äã
searchDocs.content: Recommended Path:  Connect to your Salesforce orgBrowse your agents in Configuration ExplorerChat with an agent to test behaviorView the Atlas Reasoning Engine visualizationRun a pre-built Data Cloud queryCreate your first board

searchDocs.title: Where can I learn more?‚Äã
searchDocs.content: Documentation:  Chat with AgentsConfiguration ExplorerAtlas Reasoning EngineEinstein Model TestingData Cloud IntegrationTopic Collision Analysis

searchDocs.title: Is there a tutorial?‚Äã
searchDocs.content: Yes! The extension includes:  Interactive walkthrough on first launchSample boards with examplesPre-built query templatesTooltips throughout the UI

searchDocs.title: Still Have Questions?‚Äã
searchDocs.content: Browse the full documentation starting at the GenAI Explorer Overview.    Can't find your answer? Feel free to open an issue on GitHub with your question.

searchDocs.title: Data Cloud Integration
searchDocs.keywords: data cloud queries analytics monitoring soql

searchDocs.title: The Problem‚Äã
searchDocs.content: Analyzing AI performance requires querying Data Cloud to understand conversations, token usage, errors, and agent behavior.  Teams need to:  üìä Monitor Performance: Track agent success rates, response times, and user satisfactionüí∞ Analyze Costs: Understand token consumption patterns and optimize spendingüêõ Debug Issues: Investigate errors and failed conversationsüìà Identify Trends: Spot patterns in user queries and agent responsesüîç Audit Behavior: Review what agents are doing and why‚ö° Real-Time Insights: Get immediate visibility into AI operations  In short: You need quick access to AI data for analysis and optimization without writing complex SQL queries.

searchDocs.title: How GenAI Explorer Solves This‚Äã
searchDocs.content: GenAI Explorer provides instant data access with:  ‚úÖ Pre-Built Query Library: 8+ ready-to-use analytics queries  Complete reasoning tracesToken usage by modelConversation threadingFeature usage statisticsSafety and compliance metricsError analysisPerformance trends  ‚úÖ Interactive Query Builder: Build custom queries with auto-complete  Object and field suggestionsSyntax validationQuery optimization tips  ‚úÖ Live Data Execution: Run queries directly against your org  Real-time resultsNo external tools neededSecure OAuth authentication  ‚úÖ Multiple Export Formats: Get data where you need it  CSV for ExcelJSON for APIsText for reportsCopy to clipboard  ‚úÖ Query Lab in Atlas: Specialized queries for reasoning engine analysis  Stage-by-stage performanceReAct loop iterationsRAG retrieval effectiveness  Impact: Analyze AI performance in minutes instead of days, export data instantly, and make data-driven optimization decisions without SQL expertise.

searchDocs.title: Overview‚Äã
searchDocs.content: GenAI Explorer provides deep integration with Salesforce Data Cloud, allowing you to query, analyze, and monitor all aspects of your AI implementation. Access real-time data about requests, responses, token usage, conversations, and performance metrics.

searchDocs.title: GenAI Gateway Request‚Äã
searchDocs.content: Purpose: Incoming AI requests from users and agents.  Key Fields:  Id - Unique request identifierInputText__c - User's input/querySessionId__c - Conversation session IDUserId__c - User who made the requestAgentId__c - AI Agent being queriedFeatureType__c - Type of AI feature usedActionInvoked__c - Actions requestedCreatedDate - Timestamp of requestModelRequested__c - AI model requestedTemperature__c - Model temperature parameterMaxTokens__c - Maximum tokens allowed  Common Queries:  -- Recent requests SELECT Id, InputText__c, CreatedDate, UserId__c FROM GenAIGatewayRequest__c WHERE CreatedDate = TODAY ORDER BY CreatedDate DESC -- Requests by user SELECT UserId__c, COUNT(Id) as RequestCount FROM GenAIGatewayRequest__c WHERE CreatedDate = LAST_N_DAYS:7 GROUP BY UserId__c -- Requests by agent SELECT AgentId__c, COUNT(Id) as RequestCount FROM GenAIGatewayRequest__c WHERE CreatedDate = LAST_N_DAYS:30 GROUP BY AgentId__c

searchDocs.title: GenAI Gateway Response‚Äã
searchDocs.content: Purpose: AI-generated responses to requests.  Key Fields:  Id - Unique response identifierRequestId__c - Foreign key to RequestOutputText__c - AI-generated responseCitedSources__c - References usedResponseTimeMs__c - Time to generateQualityScore__c - Quality assessmentSafetyScore__c - Safety assessmentPIIDetected__c - PII detection flagPIIMasked__c - PII masking appliedToxicityScore__c - Toxicity levelBiasScore__c - Bias detection scoreErrorMessage__c - Error details if failedCreatedDate - Response timestamp  Common Queries:  -- Responses with citations SELECT r.InputText__c, resp.OutputText__c, resp.CitedSources__c FROM GenAIGatewayRequest__c r JOIN GenAIGatewayResponse__c resp ON r.Id = resp.RequestId__c WHERE resp.CitedSources__c != null ORDER BY r.CreatedDate DESC -- Quality analysis SELECT AVG(QualityScore__c) as AvgQuality, AVG(ResponseTimeMs__c) as AvgResponseTime, COUNT(Id) as TotalResponses FROM GenAIGatewayResponse__c WHERE CreatedDate = LAST_N_DAYS:7 -- Safety monitoring SELECT Id, RequestId__c, SafetyScore__c, ToxicityScore__c FROM GenAIGatewayResponse__c WHERE SafetyScore__c < 0.8 OR ToxicityScore__c > 0.3 ORDER BY CreatedDate DESC

searchDocs.title: GenAI Gateway Generation‚Äã
searchDocs.content: Purpose: Token-level details about AI generation.  Key Fields:  Id - Unique generation identifierResponseId__c - Foreign key to ResponseModel__c - Actual model usedInputTokens__c - Input token countOutputTokens__c - Output token countTotalTokens__c - Total tokens usedCostEstimate__c - Estimated costProcessingTimeMs__c - Processing time per stageModelParameters__c - Model settings usedCreatedDate - Generation timestamp  Common Queries:  -- Token usage by model SELECT Model__c, SUM(InputTokens__c) as TotalInput, SUM(OutputTokens__c) as TotalOutput, SUM(TotalTokens__c) as TotalTokens, AVG(TotalTokens__c) as AvgPerRequest, SUM(CostEstimate__c) as TotalCost FROM GenAIGatewayGeneration__c WHERE CreatedDate = LAST_N_DAYS:30 GROUP BY Model__c -- Expensive requests SELECT g.ResponseId__c, g.TotalTokens__c, g.CostEstimate__c, r.InputText__c FROM GenAIGatewayGeneration__c g JOIN GenAIGatewayResponse__c resp ON g.ResponseId__c = resp.Id JOIN GenAIGatewayRequest__c r ON resp.RequestId__c = r.Id WHERE g.TotalTokens__c > 2000 ORDER BY g.TotalTokens__c DESC

searchDocs.title: Pre-Built Queries‚Äã
searchDocs.content: GenAI Explorer includes pre-built queries for common analysis tasks:

searchDocs.title: 1. Complete Request-Response Trace‚Äã
searchDocs.content: Purpose: Follow the full lifecycle of an AI interaction.  Query:  SELECT r.Id as RequestId, r.CreatedDate, r.InputText__c, r.SessionId__c, r.UserId__c, resp.OutputText__c, resp.ResponseTimeMs__c, resp.QualityScore__c, resp.CitedSources__c, gen.Model__c, gen.TotalTokens__c, gen.CostEstimate__c FROM GenAIGatewayRequest__c r JOIN GenAIGatewayResponse__c resp ON r.Id = resp.RequestId__c JOIN GenAIGatewayGeneration__c gen ON resp.Id = gen.ResponseId__c WHERE r.CreatedDate = TODAY ORDER BY r.CreatedDate DESC LIMIT 100   Use Case: Debug specific interactions, understand what happened end-to-end.

searchDocs.title: 2. Token Usage Analysis‚Äã
searchDocs.content: Purpose: Analyze costs and optimize model selection.  Query:  SELECT gen.Model__c, COUNT(DISTINCT r.SessionId__c) as SessionCount, COUNT(gen.Id) as RequestCount, SUM(gen.InputTokens__c) as TotalInputTokens, SUM(gen.OutputTokens__c) as TotalOutputTokens, SUM(gen.TotalTokens__c) as TotalTokens, AVG(gen.TotalTokens__c) as AvgTokensPerRequest, SUM(gen.CostEstimate__c) as TotalCost, AVG(gen.CostEstimate__c) as AvgCostPerRequest FROM GenAIGatewayGeneration__c gen JOIN GenAIGatewayResponse__c resp ON gen.ResponseId__c = resp.Id JOIN GenAIGatewayRequest__c r ON resp.RequestId__c = r.Id WHERE gen.CreatedDate = LAST_N_DAYS:30 GROUP BY gen.Model__c ORDER BY TotalCost DESC   Use Case: Identify cost optimization opportunities.

searchDocs.title: 3. Conversation Threading‚Äã
searchDocs.content: Purpose: Analyze multi-turn conversations.  Query:  SELECT r.SessionId__c, COUNT(r.Id) as MessageCount, MIN(r.CreatedDate) as SessionStart, MAX(r.CreatedDate) as SessionEnd, TIMEDIFF(MAX(r.CreatedDate), MIN(r.CreatedDate)) as SessionDuration, AVG(gen.TotalTokens__c) as AvgTokensPerMessage, SUM(gen.TotalTokens__c) as TotalSessionTokens, AVG(resp.ResponseTimeMs__c) as AvgResponseTime FROM GenAIGatewayRequest__c r JOIN GenAIGatewayResponse__c resp ON r.Id = resp.RequestId__c JOIN GenAIGatewayGeneration__c gen ON resp.Id = gen.ResponseId__c WHERE r.CreatedDate = LAST_N_DAYS:7 AND r.SessionId__c != null GROUP BY r.SessionId__c HAVING MessageCount > 1 ORDER BY MessageCount DESC, SessionStart DESC   Use Case: Understand conversation patterns and session behavior.

searchDocs.title: 4. Performance Monitoring‚Äã
searchDocs.content: Purpose: Track response times and identify bottlenecks.  Query:  SELECT r.AgentId__c, COUNT(resp.Id) as TotalResponses, AVG(resp.ResponseTimeMs__c) as AvgResponseTime, MIN(resp.ResponseTimeMs__c) as MinResponseTime, MAX(resp.ResponseTimeMs__c) as MaxResponseTime, PERCENTILE(resp.ResponseTimeMs__c, 0.5) as MedianResponseTime, PERCENTILE(resp.ResponseTimeMs__c, 0.95) as P95ResponseTime, AVG(resp.QualityScore__c) as AvgQualityScore FROM GenAIGatewayRequest__c r JOIN GenAIGatewayResponse__c resp ON r.Id = resp.RequestId__c WHERE r.CreatedDate = LAST_N_DAYS:7 GROUP BY r.AgentId__c ORDER BY AvgResponseTime DESC   Use Case: Identify slow agents and optimize performance.

searchDocs.title: 5. Feature Usage Analysis‚Äã
searchDocs.content: Purpose: Track which AI features are most used.  Query:  SELECT r.FeatureType__c, r.ActionInvoked__c, COUNT(r.Id) as UsageCount, COUNT(DISTINCT r.UserId__c) as UniqueUsers, AVG(resp.ResponseTimeMs__c) as AvgResponseTime, AVG(resp.QualityScore__c) as AvgQuality, COUNT(CASE WHEN resp.ErrorMessage__c != null THEN 1 END) as ErrorCount, (COUNT(CASE WHEN resp.ErrorMessage__c != null THEN 1 END) * 100.0 / COUNT(r.Id)) as ErrorRate FROM GenAIGatewayRequest__c r JOIN GenAIGatewayResponse__c resp ON r.Id = resp.RequestId__c WHERE r.CreatedDate = LAST_N_DAYS:30 GROUP BY r.FeatureType__c, r.ActionInvoked__c ORDER BY UsageCount DESC   Use Case: Understand feature adoption and prioritize improvements.

searchDocs.title: 6. Safety & Compliance Monitoring‚Äã
searchDocs.content: Purpose: Track PII detection, masking, and safety scores.  Query:  SELECT r.CreatedDate, r.UserId__c, r.AgentId__c, resp.SafetyScore__c, resp.PIIDetected__c, resp.PIIMasked__c, resp.ToxicityScore__c, resp.BiasScore__c, CASE WHEN resp.SafetyScore__c < 0.7 THEN 'High Risk' WHEN resp.SafetyScore__c < 0.85 THEN 'Medium Risk' ELSE 'Low Risk' END as RiskLevel FROM GenAIGatewayRequest__c r JOIN GenAIGatewayResponse__c resp ON r.Id = resp.RequestId__c WHERE r.CreatedDate = LAST_N_DAYS:30 AND (resp.SafetyScore__c < 0.8 OR resp.PIIDetected__c = true OR resp.ToxicityScore__c > 0.3 OR resp.BiasScore__c > 0.3) ORDER BY resp.SafetyScore__c ASC, r.CreatedDate DESC   Use Case: Compliance auditing and safety monitoring.

searchDocs.title: 7. User Engagement Analysis‚Äã
searchDocs.content: Purpose: Track user adoption and engagement.  Query:  SELECT r.UserId__c, COUNT(DISTINCT DATE(r.CreatedDate)) as ActiveDays, COUNT(r.Id) as TotalRequests, COUNT(DISTINCT r.SessionId__c) as TotalSessions, AVG(resp.QualityScore__c) as AvgQualityScore, SUM(gen.TotalTokens__c) as TotalTokensUsed, MIN(r.CreatedDate) as FirstRequest, MAX(r.CreatedDate) as LastRequest FROM GenAIGatewayRequest__c r JOIN GenAIGatewayResponse__c resp ON r.Id = resp.RequestId__c JOIN GenAIGatewayGeneration__c gen ON resp.Id = gen.ResponseId__c WHERE r.CreatedDate = LAST_N_DAYS:30 GROUP BY r.UserId__c ORDER BY TotalRequests DESC   Use Case: Understand user adoption and identify power users.

searchDocs.title: 8. Error Analysis‚Äã
searchDocs.content: Purpose: Identify and track errors.  Query:  SELECT DATE(r.CreatedDate) as ErrorDate, r.AgentId__c, resp.ErrorMessage__c, COUNT(resp.Id) as ErrorCount, COUNT(DISTINCT r.UserId__c) as AffectedUsers FROM GenAIGatewayRequest__c r JOIN GenAIGatewayResponse__c resp ON r.Id = resp.RequestId__c WHERE r.CreatedDate = LAST_N_DAYS:7 AND resp.ErrorMessage__c != null GROUP BY DATE(r.CreatedDate), r.AgentId__c, resp.ErrorMessage__c ORDER BY ErrorDate DESC, ErrorCount DESC   Use Case: Track and prioritize bug fixes.

searchDocs.title: Request Replay & Debugging Tools
searchDocs.keywords: replay debugging prompts optimization testing ai-powered

searchDocs.title: The Problem‚Äã
searchDocs.content: Debugging and optimizing AI responses requires the ability to replay requests, experiment with variations, and compare results.  Teams need to:  üîÑ Replay Historical Requests: Re-run past conversations to verify fixes or test improvementsüî¨ Experiment Safely: Test prompt variations without affecting productionüìä Compare Results: See how different prompts or models respond to the same inputüéØ Optimize Iteratively: Refine prompts based on actual resultsüêõ Debug Systematically: Isolate which part of a request caused an issue‚ö° Speed Up Testing: Validate changes without waiting for real user traffic  In short: You need a testing lab to iterate on AI requests and validate improvements before deployment.

searchDocs.title: How GenAI Explorer Solves This‚Äã
searchDocs.content: GenAI Explorer provides complete request replay and debugging with:  ‚úÖ Request Replay: Replay any historical GenAI request exactly as it was  Same prompt, same model, same parametersCompare original vs new responses side-by-sideVerify bug fixes instantly  ‚úÖ Prompt Editing: Edit prompts before replaying to test variations  A/B test different approachesOptimize for clarity and efficiencyFix issues quickly without deployment  ‚úÖ AI-Powered Optimization: Use AI to suggest prompt improvements  Einstein analyzes your prompt for clarity, specificity, structure, and token efficiencyGet improved version automaticallyLearn best practices through suggestions  ‚úÖ Debug Query Builder: See exact SQL queries being executed  Copy queries to run in Data CloudUnderstand data flow completelyTroubleshoot data issues efficiently  ‚úÖ Side-by-Side Comparison: View original vs replay results with metrics  Response quality differencesToken usage changesProcessing time comparison  Impact: Reduce debugging time by 80%, optimize prompts with confidence, and iterate 10x faster on AI improvements.

searchDocs.title: Button Actions‚Äã
searchDocs.content: 1. Replay Button (‚ñ∂Ô∏è)‚Äã  Purpose: Replay the request exactly as it was  When to Use:  Verify if a bug still existsCompare current model behavior vs historicalTest infrastructure changesValidate fixes  What Happens:    Result:  Original response (from history)New response (from replay)Comparison highlighting differences  2. Edit Button (‚úèÔ∏è)‚Äã  Purpose: Modify the prompt before replaying  When to Use:  Test prompt variationsFix known issuesAdd context or constraintsOptimize for better results  What Happens:  Prompt becomes editableMake your changesClick Replay to testClick Undo to revert  Example Workflow:  Original Prompt: "Tell me about this customer" Edited Prompt: "Provide a concise summary of this customer including: - Account status - Recent orders (last 30 days) - Open cases - Renewal date" ‚Üí Click Replay to test improved prompt   3. Suggest Button (ü§ñ)‚Äã  Purpose: Use AI to suggest prompt improvements  When to Use:  Prompt is unclear or vagueWant to optimize token usageNeed better structureSeeking best practices  What Happens:    Meta-Prompt Used:  You are an AI prompt engineering expert. Analyze the following prompt and suggest improvements to make it clearer, more specific, and more effective. Consider: - Clarity and specificity - Structure and formatting - Context and examples - Token efficiency Original prompt: """ [Your prompt here] """ Provide an improved version of the prompt. Only return the improved prompt text, without explanations.   Example Transformation:  Before (Vague):  Help with order   After AI Suggestion (Specific):  Please provide the following information about the customer's order: 1. Order Status: Current state (e.g., Processing, Shipped, Delivered) 2. Tracking Number: If available and order has shipped 3. Estimated Delivery: Expected delivery date and time window 4. Items Ordered: List of products with quantities 5. Order Total: Final amount including tax and shipping Format the response in a clear, customer-friendly manner.

searchDocs.content: In Any Session View:  Look for the "üîΩ Hide Debug Queries" button at the topClick to toggle query visibilitySee queries for current tab (Overview, Interactions, Messages, Steps)  Debug Panel Components:  ‚îå‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îê ‚îÇ üîç Query Being Executed: ‚îÇ ‚îÇ ‚îÇ ‚îÇ ‚îå‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îê ‚îÇ ‚îÇ ‚îÇ SELECT ssot__Id__c, ssot__MessageText__c, ‚îÇ ‚îÇ ‚îÇ ‚îÇ ssot__MessageRole__c, ssot__Timestamp__c ‚îÇ ‚îÇ ‚îÇ ‚îÇ FROM ssot__AiAgentInteractionMessage__dlm ‚îÇ ‚îÇ ‚îÇ ‚îÇ WHERE ssot__AiAgentInteractionId__c IN ( ‚îÇ ‚îÇ ‚îÇ ‚îÇ SELECT ssot__Id__c ‚îÇ ‚îÇ ‚îÇ ‚îÇ FROM ssot__AiAgentInteraction__dlm ‚îÇ ‚îÇ ‚îÇ ‚îÇ WHERE ssot__AiAgentSessionId__c = 'a4j5g...' ‚îÇ ‚îÇ ‚îÇ ‚îÇ ) ‚îÇ ‚îÇ ‚îÇ ‚îÇ ORDER BY ssot__Timestamp__c ASC ‚îÇ ‚îÇ ‚îÇ ‚îÇ ‚îÇ ‚îÇ ‚îÇ ‚îÇ [üìã Copy] [‚ñ∂Ô∏è Run Query] ‚îÇ ‚îÇ ‚îÇ ‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îò ‚îÇ ‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îò

searchDocs.title: Query Examples‚Äã
searchDocs.content: 1. Load Session Interactions‚Äã  SELECT ssot__Id__c, ssot__AiAgentInteractionType__c, ssot__TopicApiName__c, ssot__StartTimestamp__c, ssot__EndTimestamp__c FROM ssot__AiAgentInteraction__dlm WHERE ssot__AiAgentSessionId__c = '{sessionId}' ORDER BY ssot__StartTimestamp__c ASC   2. Load Conversation Messages‚Äã  SELECT m.ssot__Id__c, m.ssot__MessageText__c, m.ssot__MessageRole__c, m.ssot__Timestamp__c, m.ssot__TokenCount__c FROM ssot__AiAgentInteractionMessage__dlm m WHERE m.ssot__AiAgentInteractionId__c IN ( SELECT ssot__Id__c FROM ssot__AiAgentInteraction__dlm WHERE ssot__AiAgentSessionId__c = '{sessionId}' ) ORDER BY m.ssot__Timestamp__c ASC   3. Load Processing Steps‚Äã  SELECT s.ssot__Id__c, s.ssot__StepType__c, s.ssot__ActionName__c, s.ssot__StartTimestamp__c, s.ssot__EndTimestamp__c, s.ssot__ErrorMessage__c FROM ssot__AiAgentInteractionStep__dlm s WHERE s.ssot__AiAgentInteractionId__c IN ( SELECT ssot__Id__c FROM ssot__AiAgentInteraction__dlm WHERE ssot__AiAgentSessionId__c = '{sessionId}' ) ORDER BY s.ssot__StartTimestamp__c ASC

searchDocs.title: Workflow 3: Optimize High-Token Prompts‚Äã
searchDocs.content: Problem: Request uses too many tokens (expensive)  Steps:  Find high-token request in Query LabSort by totalTokens__c descendingOpen top requestClick "Suggest" buttonAI analyzes and suggests optimized versionReview suggestions: Removed redundancyMore concise languageBetter structureFewer tokens Click "Replay" to verifyCompare token usage: Before: 1,500 tokensAfter: 800 tokensSavings: 47%

searchDocs.title: Workflow 4: Trace Request Through Pipeline‚Äã
searchDocs.content: Problem: Need to understand full request flow  Steps:  Open request in ExplorerNote gatewayRequestId__cSwitch to Atlas Reasoning EngineUse "Complete Reasoning Trace" queryFilter by request IDSee all 6 stages: Stage 1: Chit-Chat DetectionStage 2: Query EvaluationStage 3: Context RefinementStage 4: Query PlanningStage 5: Advanced RetrievalStage 6: Safety Gates Identify bottleneck or issueOptimize that specific stage

searchDocs.title: 1. Request Replay‚Äã
searchDocs.content: ‚úÖ DO:  Test in sandbox firstCompare side-by-sideDocument changes madeTrack performance metricsTest edge cases  ‚ùå DON'T:  Replay in production without testingChange multiple variables at onceIgnore token cost implicationsSkip comparison analysis

searchDocs.title: 2. Prompt Optimization‚Äã
searchDocs.content: ‚úÖ DO:  Use AI suggestions as starting pointTest optimized prompts thoroughlyMeasure token savingsValidate quality maintainedDocument improvements  ‚ùå DON'T:  Blindly accept AI suggestionsOptimize for tokens at expense of qualitySkip A/B testingForget context requirements

searchDocs.title: 3. Debug Query Usage‚Äã
searchDocs.content: ‚úÖ DO:  Copy queries for documentationShare queries with teamRun queries in Query Lab for deeper analysisCheck permissions if queries failVerify field names match your org  ‚ùå DON'T:  Modify production data via queriesExpose sensitive data in query resultsRun queries without understanding themIgnore query performance

searchDocs.title: 1. Replay Optimization‚Äã
searchDocs.content: Cache responses during testing to avoid redundant API callsBatch replay multiple variations to compare efficientlyUse cheaper models (GPT-4o-mini) for initial testingSet token limits to prevent runaway costs

searchDocs.title: 2. Query Optimization‚Äã
searchDocs.content: Add date filters to limit data scannedUse indexed fields for WHERE clausesLimit results with LIMIT clause**Avoid SELECT *** on large tables

searchDocs.title: 3. Debugging Efficiency‚Äã
searchDocs.content: Start with recent data (LAST_N_DAYS:7)Filter by session ID when possibleUse query builder to validate syntaxExport results for offline analysis

searchDocs.title: Issue: Replay Button Disabled‚Äã
searchDocs.content: Causes:  No AI mode configured (OpenAI, Einstein, etc.)No prompt available (masked or null)Already replaying (button shows "Replaying...")  Solution:  Configure AI mode in SettingsVerify prompt field has dataWait for current replay to complete

searchDocs.title: Topic Collision Analysis
searchDocs.keywords: topic collision topics routing einstein optimization orthogonal

searchDocs.title: The Problem‚Äã
searchDocs.content: As your agent implementation grows with more topics, ensuring they don't overlap or conflict becomes increasingly complex.  Teams need to:  üéØ Prevent Routing Confusion: Ensure each user message is routed to the correct, most specific topicüîç Identify Overlaps: Detect when multiple topics could handle the same query‚öñÔ∏è Maintain Consistency: Provide predictable, reliable responses to usersüìä Scale Confidently: Add new topics without breaking existing routingüé® Optimize Scope: Define clear boundaries for each topic's responsibility‚úÖ Validate Changes: Test topic updates before deploying to production  In short: You need a way to ensure your topics are orthogonal (non-overlapping) so users get routed to the right place every time.

searchDocs.title: How GenAI Explorer Solves This‚Äã
searchDocs.content: GenAI Explorer uses Einstein AI analysis to:  ‚úÖ Automatic Detection: Einstein analyzes all topic pairs and identifies overlaps with precision scores  ‚úÖ Overlap Scoring: See exactly how much topics overlap (0-100%) and why  ‚úÖ Root Cause Analysis: Einstein explains why topics collide with clear reasoning  ‚úÖ Specific Resolutions: Get 2-3 actionable suggestions per collision (merge, refine scope, add exclusions)  ‚úÖ Visual Comparison: See overlapping vs orthogonal topics side-by-side with diagrams  ‚úÖ Resolution Strategies: Learn 5 proven approaches to fix collisions (scope refinement, merging, exclusions, splitting, hierarchy)  Impact: Achieve 95%+ topic classification accuracy, eliminate routing inconsistencies, and build reliable agents users can trust.

searchDocs.title: Overview‚Äã
searchDocs.content: The Topic Collision Analysis feature uses Einstein AI to detect when multiple topics in a GenAI Planner have overlapping scopes. Since topics are used to classify incoming messages, they must be orthogonal (non-overlapping) to ensure proper message routing and classification.

searchDocs.title: Why This Matters‚Äã
searchDocs.content: When topics have overlapping scopes:  Classification Ambiguity: A single user message could match multiple topicsRouting Failures: The system cannot determine which topic should handle the messageInconsistent Behavior: Similar messages may be routed to different topics unpredictablyPoor User Experience: Users receive incorrect or incomplete responses

searchDocs.title: 1. Analysis Trigger‚Äã
searchDocs.content: When viewing a GenAI Planner, you'll see an alert prompting you to analyze topics:  Topic Scope Analysis Use Einstein to analyze topic scopes for potential collisions. Topics must be orthogonal to properly classify messages. [Analyze Button]

searchDocs.title: 2. Einstein Analysis Process‚Äã
searchDocs.content: When clicked, the system:  Gathers Topic Information: Collects all topic metadata including: Master Label and Developer NameDescriptionScope definitionPlugin Type Calls Einstein API: Sends a structured prompt asking Einstein to: Compare each pair of topicsCalculate overlap scores (0.0 to 1.0)Identify why topics overlapSuggest specific resolutions Displays Results: Shows a comprehensive analysis with actionable recommendations

searchDocs.title: 3. Analysis Results‚Äã
searchDocs.content: No Collisions Detected ‚úì‚Äã  ‚úì No Topic Collisions Detected All topics have orthogonal scopes and should classify messages correctly.   Collisions Detected ‚ö†Ô∏è‚Äã  When collisions are found, the system displays:  For each collision:  Topic Pair: Shows which two topics overlapOverlap Score: Percentage indicating severity (e.g., "75% overlap")Overlap Reason: Detailed explanation from EinsteinSuggested Resolutions: 2-3 specific actions to resolve the collision  Example:  ‚ö†Ô∏è Topic Scope Collisions Detected Found 2 potential collision(s). Topics with overlapping scopes may cause classification failures. ‚îå‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îê ‚îÇ [Customer Support] overlaps with [Product Inquiries] 75% ‚îÇ ‚îÇ ‚îÇ ‚îÇ Reason: Both topics handle customer questions about ‚îÇ ‚îÇ product features and troubleshooting. ‚îÇ ‚îÇ ‚îÇ ‚îÇ Suggested Resolutions: ‚îÇ ‚îÇ ‚Ä¢ Narrow Customer Support to only handle technical issues ‚îÇ ‚îÇ ‚Ä¢ Limit Product Inquiries to pre-sales questions only ‚îÇ ‚îÇ ‚Ä¢ Merge both into a comprehensive "Customer Service" topic ‚îÇ ‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îò [Re-analyze Button]

searchDocs.title: Resolution Strategies‚Äã
searchDocs.content: Einstein typically suggests these types of resolutions:

searchDocs.title: 1. Scope Refinement‚Äã
searchDocs.content: Narrow the focus of one or both topics to eliminate overlap.  Example:  Original: "Customer Support" (handles all customer questions)Refined: "Technical Support" (handles only technical issues)

searchDocs.title: 2. Topic Merging‚Äã
searchDocs.content: Combine overlapping topics into a single, comprehensive topic.  When to use:  Topics have >70% overlapSeparating them adds no value to usersThey share the same underlying knowledge base

searchDocs.title: 3. Exclusion Criteria‚Äã
searchDocs.content: Add explicit boundaries to topic scopes.  Example:  Topic A: "Product Questions" (excludes pricing)Topic B: "Pricing Inquiries" (only handles pricing)

searchDocs.title: 4. Topic Splitting‚Äã
searchDocs.content: Break down overly broad topics into more specific ones.  Example:  Original: "General Inquiries" (too broad)Split into: "Account Questions""Billing Questions""Technical Questions"

searchDocs.title: 5. Hierarchy Creation‚Äã
searchDocs.content: Establish parent-child relationships between topics.  Example:  Parent: "Customer Service" Child: "Returns & Refunds"Child: "Order Status"Child: "Product Support"

searchDocs.title: 1. Regular Analysis‚Äã
searchDocs.content: Run analysis after adding new topicsRe-analyze when modifying topic scopesCheck periodically as part of planner maintenance

searchDocs.title: 2. Topic Design Guidelines‚Äã
searchDocs.content: DO:  ‚úì Create specific, focused topics‚úì Use clear, descriptive scope definitions‚úì Document exclusions and boundaries‚úì Test with sample messages  DON'T:  ‚úó Create overly broad "catch-all" topics‚úó Use vague scope descriptions‚úó Ignore overlap warnings‚úó Duplicate functionality across topics

searchDocs.title: 3. Testing Recommendations‚Äã
searchDocs.content: After resolving collisions:  Test with real user messagesMonitor classification accuracyReview routing patternsAdjust scopes based on actual usage

searchDocs.title: User Workflow‚Äã
searchDocs.content: Navigate to a GenAI Planner in SF ExplorerClick the "Analyze" button in the Topic Scope Analysis sectionReview any detected collisionsImplement suggested resolutions: Edit topic scopes in SalesforceMerge or split topics as neededUpdate descriptions and instructions Re-analyze to verify fixesTest with sample messages to confirm proper routing

searchDocs.title: API Integration‚Äã
searchDocs.content: The feature uses Einstein's LLM Completions API:  const einsteinEndpoint = `/services/data/v60.0/einstein/llm/completions` const requestBody = { prompt: analysisPrompt, model: "sfdc_ai__DefaultGPT4Omni", maxTokens: 2000, temperature: 0.3, // Low temperature for consistent analysis responseFormat: { type: "json_object" } }

searchDocs.title: Fallback Analysis‚Äã
searchDocs.content: If Einstein API is unavailable, the system performs basic text similarity analysis:  Compares topic names, descriptions, and scopesCalculates Jaccard similarity coefficientSuggests generic resolutions  This ensures the feature remains functional even without Einstein access.

searchDocs.title: Issue: False Positives‚Äã
searchDocs.content: Symptom: Topics flagged as overlapping but shouldn't be  Solution:  Review Einstein's reasoningCheck if scope descriptions are unclearAdd more specific scope detailsRe-run analysis

searchDocs.title: Issue: Einstein API Errors‚Äã
searchDocs.content: Symptom: Analysis fails with API error  Solution:  Fallback analysis will run automaticallyCheck Einstein API permissionsVerify org has Einstein features enabledContact Salesforce support if persistent

searchDocs.title: Issue: No Collisions Detected (But Problems Exist)‚Äã
searchDocs.content: Symptom: Analysis shows no issues but messages route incorrectly  Solution:  Check topic instructions (not just scopes)Review actual message classification logsTest with specific problematic messagesConsider semantic overlaps Einstein might miss

searchDocs.title: Next Steps‚Äã
searchDocs.content: Configuration Explorer - View all your topics and agentsChat with Agents - Test message routing with sample conversationsFAQ - Frequently asked questions

searchDocs.title: Test Case Editing
searchDocs.keywords: agentforce test cases evaluation testing quality assurance ai testing

searchDocs.title: The Problem‚Äã
searchDocs.content: Testing AI agents requires constant refinement of test cases based on actual agent behavior.  When building and testing AI agents, teams face challenges:  üîÑ Iterative Refinement: Test expectations need frequent updates as agents evolveüëÄ Comparison Difficulty: Hard to compare expected vs actual results side-by-side‚ö° Action Discovery: Finding which actions are available for a specific topicüìù Input Variations: Testing different phrasings of the same questionüéØ Manual Verification: Time-consuming to verify each test result manuallyüîÅ Status Updates: Need to re-run tests to see if changes fixed issues  In short: You need a streamlined way to edit test cases while comparing actual agent behavior with expected outcomes.

searchDocs.title: How GenAI Explorer Solves This‚Äã
searchDocs.content: GenAI Explorer provides comprehensive test case editing with:  ‚úÖ Side-by-Side Comparison: See actual vs expected values in one glance  Actual results on the LEFT (what the agent did)Expected values on the RIGHT (what you want)Natural left-to-right reading flow  ‚úÖ Smart Action Filtering: Topic-aware action selection  Multi-select checkboxes for actionsAutomatically filtered by selected topicShows only relevant actions for the topic  ‚úÖ Full Editability: Edit both inputs and outputs  User utterance (question)Expected topicExpected actions (multi-select)Expected bot response  ‚úÖ Auto-Recalculation: Instant feedback  Test status recalculates after savingSee pass/fail immediatelyNo need to manually re-run tests  ‚úÖ Visual Feedback: Color-coded comparison  üü¢ Green: Actual values (from agent)üîµ Blue/Orange: Expected values (editable)Clear visual distinction between the two  Impact: Reduce test maintenance time by 70%, catch issues earlier with side-by-side comparison, and refine test cases 3x faster with smart action filtering.

searchDocs.title: Overview‚Äã
searchDocs.content: The Test Case Editing interface allows you to modify test expectations while viewing actual agent results side-by-side. This makes it easy to update test cases when agent behavior changes or when you need to refine your expectations.

searchDocs.title: Test Cases Table Features‚Äã

searchDocs.content: Characteristics:  Color: Green stylingEditable: No (read-only)Purpose: Shows what the agent actually didVisual: Chips for topics/actions, text for responses  Display:  Topics: Green chips with topic namesActions: Green chips for each actionResponse: Green bordered box with full textEmpty states: "No topic/actions/response from agent yet"

searchDocs.title: Reading Flow‚Äã
searchDocs.content: Natural left-to-right workflow:  üëÄ Look at Actual (left) - See what the agent didü§î Decide if it's correct - Is this what you expected?‚úèÔ∏è Adjust Expected (right) - Update if neededüíæ Save - Persist changes  Example Workflow:  User utterance: "What is my account balance?" Step 1: Run test Actual Topic: [ServiceTopic_v2] ‚Üê Left side Actual Actions: [GetBalance] ‚Üê Left side Actual Response: "Your balance is $1,234.56" ‚Üê Left side Step 2: Agent looks good! Copy to expected Expected Topic: ServiceTopic_v2 ‚Üê Right side Expected Actions: ‚òë GetBalance ‚Üê Right side Expected Response: "$1,234.56" ‚Üê Right side (simplified) Step 3: Save changes ‚Üí Status recalculates ‚Üí Test shows "Success" ‚úÖ

searchDocs.title: What Happens After Saving‚Äã
searchDocs.content: When you click "Save Changes", the system automatically:  ‚úÖ Saves your edits to the test case metadataüîÑ Recalculates matches against actual sessionsüìä Updates test status (Success/Partial/Error/No Match)üéØ Refreshes the table with new results  You don't need to:  Manually refresh the pageRe-run the testWait for async processesClick any additional buttons

searchDocs.title: Status Indicators‚Äã
searchDocs.content: After recalculation, you'll see updated status:  üü¢ Success  All expectations match actual resultsTopic matchesAll actions executedResponse matches (if specified)  üü° Partial  Some expectations matchExample: Topic matches but actions don'tExample: Actions match but response differs  üî¥ Error  Major mismatchesExample: Wrong topic identifiedExample: No actions executed when expected  ‚ö™ No Match  No agent session found for this utteranceAgent hasn't been tested with this input yetNeed to run the agent first

searchDocs.content: The recalculation typically takes < 1 second, giving you immediate feedback:  [Edit Dialog] ‚îå‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îê ‚îÇ Save Changes ‚îÇ ‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îò ‚Üì [Saving...] ‚Üì [Table Updates] ‚îå‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îê ‚îÇ Test #1: Success ‚úÖ ‚îÇ ‚îÇ - Topic: Match ‚úÖ ‚îÇ ‚îÇ - Actions: Match ‚úÖ ‚îÇ ‚îÇ - Response: Match ‚úÖ ‚îÇ ‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îò

searchDocs.content: Use Case: Agent behavior is correct, update expectations to match.  Steps:  Click ‚úèÔ∏è Edit on test caseReview left side (actual values)Copy/select same values on right side (expected) Select matching topic from dropdownCheck same actions in multi-selectCopy response text (or adjust as needed) Click "Save Changes"‚úÖ Status updates to "Success"  Time Saved: 30 seconds per test case vs. manually editing metadata.

searchDocs.content: Use Case: Agent behavior changed, expectations are outdated.  Steps:  See "Error" or "Partial" status in tableClick ‚úèÔ∏è Edit to see what's mismatchedCompare actual (left) vs expected (right)Update expected to match new agent behaviorSave and verify status changes to "Success"  Example:  Before: Expected Actions: ['GetBalance'] Actual Actions: ['GetBalance', 'CheckLimit'] Status: Partial ‚ö†Ô∏è After Edit: Expected Actions: ['GetBalance', 'CheckLimit'] Status: Success ‚úÖ

Steps:  Click ‚úèÔ∏è Edit on existing test caseModify the input utterance "What is my balance?" ‚Üí "Show my balance""What is my balance?" ‚Üí "How much money do I have?" Keep or adjust expectationsSave and see if agent still works correctly  Use Case: Ensuring your agent is robust to variations in user input.

searchDocs.content: Use Case: Agent now calls additional actions, update expectations. searchDocs.title: Workflow 5: Refine Response Expectations‚Äã
searchDocs.content: Use Case: Allow for slight variations in response wording.  Steps:  Click ‚úèÔ∏è EditSee actual response on leftDecide if exact match is neededUpdate expected response to be more flexible: "Your balance is $1,234.56" (exact)"$1,234.56" (key info only)Leave blank (don't check response) Save and verify  Pro Tip: More specific expectations catch regressions, but too strict expectations cause false failures.

searchDocs.title: How It Works‚Äã
searchDocs.content: The action multi-select is dynamically filtered based on the selected topic:  Step 1: Select a topic Selected Topic: "ServiceTopic" ‚Üì Step 2: Actions filter automatically Available Actions: - GetBalance ‚Üê Only actions from ServiceTopic - TransferFunds ‚Üê Only actions from ServiceTopic - CheckAccountLimit ‚Üê Only actions from ServiceTopic ‚Üì Step 3: Select actions ‚òë GetBalance ‚òë TransferFunds ‚òê CheckAccountLimit

searchDocs.title: Why This Matters‚Äã
searchDocs.content: Without filtering:  See 50+ actions from all topicsHard to find relevant actionsEasy to select wrong actionsConfusion about which actions work together  With smart filtering:  See only 3-8 actions per topicQuickly find the right actionsConfidence that actions are compatibleFaster test case creation

searchDocs.title: Visual Indicators‚Äã
searchDocs.content: When no topic selected:  Expected Actions: ‚îå‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îê ‚îÇ Select a topic first to see ‚îÇ ‚îÇ available actions ‚îÇ ‚îÇ (Dropdown disabled) ‚îÇ ‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îò   When topic selected:  Expected Actions: ‚îå‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îê ‚îÇ ‚òë GetBalance ‚îÇ ‚îÇ ‚òê TransferFunds ‚îÇ ‚îÇ ‚òê CheckLimit ‚îÇ ‚îÇ ‚òê UpdateProfile ‚îÇ ‚îÇ ‚òê ResetPassword ‚îÇ ‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îò 5 action(s) available from "ServiceTopic"   When topic has no actions:  Expected Actions: ‚îå‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îê ‚îÇ No actions found for this topic‚îÇ ‚îÇ (Dropdown disabled) ‚îÇ ‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îò

searchDocs.title: Benefits‚Äã
searchDocs.content: ‚úÖ Speed: Find actions 5x faster ‚úÖ Accuracy: Select correct actions every time ‚úÖ Discoverability: See what actions are available per topic ‚úÖ Confidence: Know actions are compatible with topic

searchDocs.title: 1. Always Compare Before Editing‚Äã
searchDocs.content: üëÄ Look at actual values on the left before making changes.  Why: You might find the agent's behavior is actually correct, just different from original expectations.

searchDocs.title: 2. Use Specific Expectations‚Äã
searchDocs.content: üéØ Be as specific as possible with expectations.  Example:  ‚ùå Bad: Expected response: "balance"‚úÖ Good: Expected response: "Your balance is $1,234.56"  Why: Specific expectations catch regressions better.

searchDocs.title: 3. Test Input Variations‚Äã
searchDocs.content: üìù Create multiple test cases for different phrasings.  Example:  Test #1: "What is my balance?"Test #2: "Show my balance"Test #3: "How much money do I have?"  Why: Ensures your agent is robust to natural language variations.

searchDocs.title: 4. Review After Agent Changes‚Äã
searchDocs.content: üîÑ When you update your agent, review all test cases.  Steps:  Check for "Error" or "Partial" statusesEdit each failed test caseDecide if agent or expectation needs fixingUpdate expectations or fix agent  Why: Keeps your test suite accurate as your agent evolves.

searchDocs.title: 5. Group Related Actions‚Äã
searchDocs.content: ‚ö° When selecting multiple actions, ensure they're logically related.  Example:  ‚úÖ Good: ['GetBalance', 'CheckAccountLimit'] - Related to account info‚ùå Bad: ['GetBalance', 'ResetPassword'] - Unrelated actions  Why: Ensures test cases represent realistic user flows.

searchDocs.title: 6. Save Incrementally‚Äã
searchDocs.content: üíæ Save your changes frequently, don't edit multiple fields at once initially.  Workflow:  Edit input utterance ‚Üí Save ‚Üí VerifyEdit expected topic ‚Üí Save ‚Üí VerifyEdit expected actions ‚Üí Save ‚Üí Verify  Why: Easier to identify what caused a test to pass or fail.

searchDocs.title: 7. Use Comments in Responses‚Äã
searchDocs.content: üí¨ Add context to complex expected responses.  Example:  Expected Response: Your balance is $1,234.56. Available credit: $500. Note: Should include both balance and available credit   Why: Helps other team members understand the expectations.

searchDocs.title: Suffix Matching‚Äã
searchDocs.content: What it is: Salesforce appends random suffixes to developer names in some orgs.  Example:  You expect: ServiceTopicAgent returns: ServiceTopic_16jgL000000oOlV  How it's handled:The system automatically matches names with and without suffixes, so:  ServiceTopic matches ServiceTopic_16jgL000000oOlVYou don't need to include the suffix in your expectationsWorks for both topics and actions  Why it matters: You can write portable test cases that work across orgs.

searchDocs.title: Partial Response Matching‚Äã
searchDocs.content: What it is: Match on key parts of the response, not exact text.  Example:  Expected: "$1,234.56" Actual: "Your current balance is $1,234.56. You have available credit of $500." Result: ‚úÖ Match (contains expected text)   How to use:  Keep expected responses short and focused on key infoDon't include filler words if they might varyFocus on facts that must be present  Why it matters: Allows for more flexible response templates while still validating key information.

searchDocs.title: Bulk Editing‚Äã
searchDocs.content: What it is: Edit multiple test cases at once (coming soon).  Planned features:  Select multiple test casesBulk update expected topicBulk update expected actionsApply changes to all selected  Use case: When you rename a topic or action, update all affected test cases at once.

searchDocs.title: "No session match" Status‚Äã
searchDocs.content: Problem: Test shows "No session match" after editing.  Possible causes:  Agent hasn't been tested with this utterance yetSession data hasn't synced from SalesforceUtterance was changed significantly  Solutions:  Run the agent with this utterance firstWait a few minutes for data syncCheck that utterance matches an actual session

searchDocs.title: Actions Dropdown Disabled‚Äã
searchDocs.content: Problem: Can't select actions in the multi-select.  Possible causes:  No topic selected yetSelected topic has no associated actionsPlanner data hasn't loaded  Solutions:  Select a topic first (required)Check that the topic has actions in your GenAiPlannerRefresh the page to reload planner data

searchDocs.title: Changes Not Saving‚Äã
searchDocs.content: Problem: Edits don't persist after clicking "Save Changes".  Possible causes:  Salesforce API errorInsufficient permissionsMetadata API limits  Solutions:  Check browser console for errorsVerify you have "Modify All Data" permissionTry again after a few minutesContact Salesforce admin

searchDocs.title: Status Not Updating‚Äã
searchDocs.content: Problem: Test status doesn't change after saving edits.  Possible causes:  Expectations still don't match actual valuesAuto-recalculation failedNeed to manually refresh  Solutions:  Review the comparison again - might still have mismatchesManually refresh the pageClick the "Refresh" button in the table toolbarCheck browser console for errors

searchDocs.title: Topics Not Loading‚Äã
searchDocs.content: Problem: Topic dropdown is empty.  Possible causes:  GenAiPlanner not configuredPlanner data hasn't loadedAPI connection issue  Solutions:  Verify your AiEvaluationDefinition has a valid GenAiPlanner referenceRefresh the pageCheck Salesforce connection statusContact admin to verify GenAiPlanner setup

searchDocs.title: Q: Can I edit multiple test cases at once?‚Äã
searchDocs.content: A: Not yet. Currently, you must edit test cases one at a time. Bulk editing is planned for a future release.

searchDocs.title: Q: What happens to my edits if I click Cancel?‚Äã
searchDocs.content: A: All changes are discarded. Only clicking "Save Changes" persists your edits to Salesforce.

searchDocs.title: Q: Can I undo changes after saving?‚Äã
searchDocs.content: A: Not directly. You would need to manually edit the test case again to revert changes. Consider keeping a backup of your test cases before major edits.

searchDocs.title: Q: Do I need to re-run the agent after editing?‚Äã
searchDocs.content: A: No. The system matches your updated expectations against existing agent sessions. However, if you change the input utterance significantly, you may need to run the agent with the new utterance to get a session match.

searchDocs.title: Q: Can I delete expectations?‚Äã
searchDocs.content: A: Yes, you can clear expected values:  Topic: Select the empty option in dropdownActions: Uncheck all actionsResponse: Clear the textarea  This effectively makes that expectation "don't check".

searchDocs.title: Q: Are changes versioned?‚Äã
searchDocs.content: A: Not currently. Changes overwrite the existing test case metadata. Consider using version control for your AiEvaluationDefinition metadata files.

searchDocs.title: Q: Can I see who edited a test case?‚Äã
searchDocs.content: A: Check the Salesforce metadata history:  Go to Setup ‚Üí Deployment StatusFind your AiEvaluationDefinition deploymentView component history

searchDocs.title: Q: How long does recalculation take?‚Äã
searchDocs.content: A: Typically < 1 second. The system queries for matching sessions and compares expectations against actual results immediately after saving.
